A Tinkering World Tour Part Two

In the spring of 2021 we launched an online workshop where we traveled to different places around the world and learned from artists, makers, and tinkerers. Participants worked on hands-on projects using everyday materials from around the house! We built handmade portraits, explored scrap craft, built wind powered machines, created digital worlds in scratch and imagined lost creatures. And throughout the experience we talked about the qualities of tinkering activities that keep us coming back over and over again.

Now, we are thrilled to announce the launch of 'Season Two' starting on September 22nd 2021! This time around the globe, we’ll be virtually visiting São Paulo, Brazil, Mexicali, Mexico, Emilia-Romagna, Italy, and Kathmandu, Nepal! This workshop we're even going to boldly go where no one has gone before and explore tinkering in ""outer space""! We'll hear from Remida Reggio Emilia in Italy, Tinkering School in USA/Mars, Colectivo Tomate in Mexico, LILO.Zone in Brazil, Karkhana in Nepal and many many more local artists makers and educators.

Our host, Ryan Jenkins of Wonderful Idea Co. will guide us again on five virtual travel experiences to different cities and countries around the world where we'll meet makers, tinkerers, artists and musicians. 

For each session we'll take a behind-the-scenes tour of a makerspace located in a library, school, public space or museum in that destination. In each city/region we'll meet a couple of artists who use the tinkering approach to work with topics like music, sustainability, cooking, technology, and community building! And each week we'll start working on a hands-on tinkering activity that can be done with everyday materials. There will be time for questions, comments and sharing experiences. 

After each session we'll post our creations on a Padlet page and share resources about the destination that will result in a wider list of tinkering-adjacent people and environments in each of our featured locations.  

As well, WICO collaborator Mariana Tamashiro will create visual notes for each session and we will share digital copies of the designs with all workshop participants. 

 

Ways to Participate in the Course

We are offering two different ways to join in on season two of the tinkering world tour! 

  • The first and most engaging way to join the workshop is live over zoom! Each week you will get a link to the zoom call and you can log in and interact with presenters and participants, build hands-on projects together, ask questions and share experiences. The two-hour workshops will take place on five Wednesdays beginning from September 22nd, 2021. The exact times for each session will differ slightly depending on the location but they will all start between 16:00 and 18:00 CEST // 7:00am - 9:00am PST. 

 

  • You can also decide to join the course on your own time, in a MOOC-style, asynchronous format. This means you will receive video recordings of the workshop on a weekly basis along with an email with extra links, resources and inspiring examples. As well, you can still participate in our online message board to share ideas, projects and questions. 

 

In our first round of the world tour we had around 80 participants from 18 different countries. We are hoping to at least double those numbers this time around!

Everyone who joined our workshop last time will get an email with a special link so you can register to participate in 'Season Two' at a discounted rate. 

If you are new to the tour, please register as soon as possible because space is limited! 

As well, all contributions to the project above and beyond the workshop fees will help us to support our guest artists and organizations, pay for technical support for the project and allow us to plan more online and hybrid workshops like this one!

Participant Feedback 

Here are some comments from participants in the first season of the Tinkering World Tour:

""the variety and juxtaposition of guests sparked serendipity and new ideas. The whole was always greater than the sum of its parts""

""the Nairobi workshop blew me away. I had not known what to expect and this first stop was just so engaging, inspiring and joyous""

""In every workshop there were a few moments/ideas that really stuck out or resonated with me and I think it was the diversity of the presenters [...] that allowed for this""

""Loved it all! Seeing the street in Kyoto did feel like being there :) Was especially excited about Berlin, as was due to go there prior to pandemic and did not get to. Now feel I got to go there virtually, and have some great places in mind to visit once we get to go in person.""

An Experimental Approach

For the workshops we will be relying on internet connections and workspace access with collaborators from around the world. We'll flexible with the workshop content and presenters and hope that all the technical details will work out. 

As well, these sessions will rely on the goodwill and enthusiasm of local partners. We will not be able to create an extensive or representative picture of all of the tinkering explorations going on in a city, region or country.  We will try to have a mix of gender, race, age and social background of  presenters and a good mix of project participants and we're always trying to make more progress in this area. 

 

Please Share Widely

Even if you can't participate in the workshop or contribute to the project, we would be really thankful if you could share our crowdfunding page on social media and with your making and tinkering networks.

The more people who see the webpage, the more help we will get to create future engaging virtual, hybrid and in-person tinkering workshops.

This time around the globe, we’ll be virtually visiting São Paulo, Brazil, Mexicali, Mexico, Emilia-Romagna, Italy, and Kathmandu, Nepal! This workshop we're even going to boldly go where no one has gone before and explore tinkering in ""outer space""! We'll hear from Remida Reggio Emilia in Italy, Tinkering School in USA/Mars, Colectivo Tomate in Mexico, LILO.Zone in Brazil, Karkhana in Nepal and many many more local artists makers and educators.Our host, Ryan Jenkins of Wonderful Idea Co. will guide us again on five virtual travel experiences to different cities and countries around the world where we'll meet makers, tinkerers, artists and musicians. For each session we'll take a behind-the-scenes tour of a makerspace located in a library, school, public space or museum in that destination. In each city/region we'll meet a couple of artists who use the tinkering approach to work with topics like music, sustainability, cooking, technology, and community building! And each week we'll start working on a hands-on tinkering activity that can be done with everyday materials. There will be time for questions, comments and sharing experiences. After each session we'll post our creations on a Padlet page and share resources about the destination that will result in a wider list of tinkering-adjacent people and environments in each of our featured locations.  As well, WICO collaborator Mariana Tamashiro will create visual notes for each session and we will share digital copies of the designs with all workshop participants.  Ways to Participate in the CourseWe are offering two different ways to join in on season two of the tinkering world tour! The first and most engaging way to join the workshop is live over zoom! Each week you will get a link to the zoom call and you can log in and interact with presenters and participants, build hands-on projects together, ask questions and share experiences. The two-hour workshops will take place on five Wednesdays beginning from September 22nd, 2021. The exact times for each session will differ slightly depending on the location but they will all start between 16:00 and 18:00 CEST // 7:00am - 9:00am PST.  You can also decide to join the course on your own time, in a MOOC-style, asynchronous format. This means you will receive video recordings of the workshop on a weekly basis along with an email with extra links, resources and inspiring examples. As well, you can still participate in our online message board to share ideas, projects and questions.  In our first round of the world tour we had around 80 participants from 18 different countries. We are hoping to at least double those numbers this time around!Everyone who joined our workshop last time will get an email with a special link so you can register to participate in 'Season Two' at a discounted rate. If you are new to the tour, please register as soon as possible because space is limited! As well, all contributions to the project above and beyond the workshop fees will help us to support our guest artists and organizations, pay for technical support for the project and allow us to plan more online and hybrid workshops like this one!Participant Feedback Here are some comments from participants in the first season of the Tinkering World Tour:""the variety and juxtaposition of guests sparked serendipity and new ideas. The whole was always greater than the sum of its parts""""the Nairobi workshop blew me away. I had not known what to expect and this first stop was just so engaging, inspiring and joyous""""In every workshop there were a few moments/ideas that really stuck out or resonated with me and I think it was the diversity of the presenters [...] that allowed for this""""Loved it all! Seeing the street in Kyoto did feel like being there :) Was especially excited about Berlin, as was due to go there prior to pandemic and did not get to. Now feel I got to go there virtually, and have some great places in mind to visit once we get to go in person.""An Experimental ApproachFor the workshops we will be relying on internet connections and workspace access with collaborators from around the world. We'll flexible with the workshop content and presenters and hope that all the technical details will work out. As well, these sessions will rely on the goodwill and enthusiasm of local partners. We will not be able to create an extensive or representative picture of all of the tinkering explorations going on in a city, region or country.  We will try to have a mix of gender, race, age and social background of  presenters and a good mix of project participants and we're always trying to make more progress in this area.  Please Share WidelyEven if you can't participate in the workshop or contribute to the project, we would be really thankful if you could share our crowdfunding page on social media and with your making and tinkering networks.The more people who see the webpage, the more help we will get to create future engaging virtual, hybrid and in-person tinkering workshops.",5.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Freiburg im Breisgau, Germany",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/wico-presents-a-tinkering-world-tour-season-two/pica

column3:
>February Update: With both Fiore books complete, I have decided to also offer them together in one giant (535-page) hardcover volume for the same donation level as both softcovers together ($200). All Fiore books will finally begin shipping this month.

November Update: Now that shirts and patches have shipped, most perks granting t-shirts and patches have been disabled to make sure we don't run out. Perks granting books and scans are still available for last-minute orders
column4: the Liechtenauer books are shipping now and the Fiore books will ship by end of year.

column1: <hr/>

column3: >Note: We forgot to address international shipping in our perk descriptions, and we can't edit a perk once a donor has claimed it. International donors please add an additional $15 if you select a t-shirt and/or DVD and an extra $30 if you order any print books.

column2: >The donation level for the Fiorist perk was mistakenly placed at $250 rather than $275. We will honor the listed price, but we would appreciate it if people selecting that perk added the extra $25 onto their donation.

column1: <div>
Short Summary

My name is Michael Chidester. I started with HEMA in 2001, and since 2009 I've been working on a project that should be familiar to all of you, the Wiktenauer (you can blame that name on Jake Norwood). Over the past five years and change we've become the unofficial library of historical European martial arts treatises from the 14th, 15th, and 16th centuries, and we're currently making inroads into the 17th. If you've missed out so far, check out that link before going further.

Maintaining and expanding this project is a volunteer effort that consumes many hundreds of hours a year, both from me and sysadmin Christian Trosclair, but hosting it is also quite expensive—and the costs increase each year. We initially funded it out of pocket, and then in 2011 convinced the HEMA Alliance to cover our costs.

Last year, we decided to try something new and held a fundraising drive. I hoped to raise $500 to cover hosting and registration, but the response was overwhelming. Ultimately we raised $3,611.93, over seven times what we asked for. We were completely unprepared for this level of funding, but I quickly started drawing up battle plans.

Where once paying for the digitization of manuscripts and books involved either finding a wealthy benefactor or passing the hat around and convincing HEMA researchers to pool funds, for the first time in 2014 we were able to begin unilaterally commissioning scans and getting permission to host them directly on the wiki.
Our acquisitions over the course of the last year included:
<ul>
• The Hans von Speyer Fechtbuch (Ms. M.I.29)
• The 1560s Joachim Meyer manuscript (Ms. A.4º.2)
• The Solothurner Fechtbuch (Cod. S.554)
• The Vienna version of Paulus Hector Mair (Cod. 10825/10826)
<li>Michael Hundt's
<a href=""http://wiktenauer.com/wiki/Ein_new_K%C5%AFnstliches_Fechtbuch_im_Rappier_(Michael_Hundt)"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""font-style: italic
column2: target=""_blank"">Ein new Kůnstliches Fechtbuch im Rappier

column1: • The Vienna version of Paulus Kal (Ms. KK 5126)
• The Gotha version of Paulus Kal (Ms. Chart. B. 1021) (partial)
• The Wolfenbüttel Sketchbook (Cod. Guelf. 78. 2. Aug. 2º)
• Domingo Luis Godinho's ""Do Arte de Esgrima"" (Ms. PBA 58)
This year we're hoping to see an even greater outpouring of support because we have a number of very interesting projects lined up.

column2: >Rapiers with secondary weapons from Michael Hundt's Ein new Kůnstliches Fechtbuch im Rappier (1611).

column1: <div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

In addition to our manuscripts acquisitions, funds from last year's drive allowed us to double our server resources. This year we'd like to double them again, and also add other server functionality that Christian assures me is necessary. That's going to come out to about $1500. If we exceed this goal, we lay out what we plan to do in the next section. (Spoiler alert: it ends with purchasing scans of the manuscript that Salvator Fabris prepared for Duke Johan Frederik of Schleswig-Holstein-Gottorp in 1601.)

To encourage donations, I've talked with a lot of people about what sorts of perks we might offer (since all of the fruits of our labor are typically given away for free). We've come up with a number of ideas, including the following:
<div style=""float: right

column3: >Patches and shirts: We just got a great new logo last month, so it's time we put it to use. John Harmston is playing with designs as we speak.

>Digital scans: People often ask for easier ways to download the scans we host on the Wiktenauer, since wikis don't really have easy export options. Choose a funding level with this perk and I will prepare a bundle of scans that you can download (or, if you prefer, I'll send you a DVD). You can request the list of scans that we acquired in 2014 (see above), you can defer your order until we've purchased all of the promised 2015 scans and have them all sent to you in a nice package, or you can order off the menu and receive up to 2 GB of scans from any that are hosted on the Wiktenauer (or that indicate that they will be hosted in the future).

>E-books: The huge compilation tables that you see on Wiktenauer got their start long before the wiki was a twinkle in Ben Michels' eye. I created the first of them in an effort to build the most complete versions of treatises possible for my students to study. To make them easier to work from, I arranged them into study books where each page presented the chief variations of a single play—the training guides that I wished I had but that no one had published (and which still haven't been published to this day).

column1: <div style=""float: left

I will take both of these documents, update them with the current translations on the wiki (including some being prepared specifically for this project) and the superior images available now, check the associations and sequence of the compilation against the current articles, and release them in three PDFs—one of Liechtenauer, two of Fiore (preface, grappling, baton, and dagger in one
column2: sword, axe, spear, and mounted in the other).

column1: <ul>

• The Liechtenauer book is 336 pages long and includes translations by Michael Chidester, Mike Rasmusson, David Rawlings, Thomas Stoeppler, Christian Tobler, Christian Trosclair, and Cory Winslow. Here is the description from the book jacket:
      ""Drawing on the manuscript scans, transcriptions, and translations hosted by Wiktenauer, this book offers the first ever compilation of the 15th century glosses of Johannes Liechtenauer's famous Recital. Each page contains a single play of the long sword or short sword, carefully laid out with the relevant glosses of Sigmund ain Ringeck, Peter von Danzig, Pseudo-Peter von Danzig, and Pseudo-Hans Döbringer side by side, and where applicable illustrated with gorgeous full-color scans from the Goliath Fechtbuch, the Glasgow Fechtbuch, and the treatises of Paulus Kal and Hans Talhoffer. In this way, it offers the most complete perspective possible on the tradition of Johannes Liechtenauer as it was recorded in the mid 15th century.""

• The Fiore books are 282 and 288 pages long (respectively) and include translations by Kendra Brown, Michael Chidester, Rebecca Garber, Colin Hatcher, and Guy Windsor—including the first-ever English translation of the Paris manuscript. Here is the description from the book jacket:
      ""Drawing on the manuscript scans, transcriptions, and translations hosted by Wiktenauer, this book offers the first ever compilation of the four known copies of the treatise of Fiore de'i Liberi. Each page contains a single play—of grappling, baton, dagger, or sword vs. dagger in volume I, and of sword, axe, spear, or mounted fencing in volume II—carefully laid out with the relevant translations and high-resolution scans from the Morgan Ms. M.303, the Getty Ms. Ludwig XV 13, the BnF Ms. Latin 11269, and Novati's 1902 facsimile of the Pisani Dossi Ms. In this way, it offers the most complete version possible of Fiore's teachings.""
<div style=""float: right

column3: >Printed books: I will take the three e-books I just described, have them printed up in color and spiral bound (so they lay flat), and ship them out. If you get a printed book, you will also receive the e-book version for use on computers.

>To be clear, these books (in digital and print form) are a repackaging of content currently on the Wiktenauer, no more, no less. The e-book you receive will match the text of the Wiktenauer articles, just organized in a way that may facilitate study (and any corrections I make in finishing the books will also be made in said articles).

>Also to be clear, neither the print book nor the e-book will ever go on sale anywhere else. Wiktenauer is not, at this time, in the publishing industry and we don't have a store. The number of books we're planning to make is capped at 94, and we'll only increase that number if demand is overwhelming. If you don't pick one up in this fundraiser, you'll have to hope that we offer a similar deal next year.

>Wiktenauer Sponsor: We will place your club or school logo and a link to your website on the front page of the wiki. We will also help you promote any activities of your group over the next year that are within the scope of our mission (historical research and manual study).

column1: <div>
Stretch Goals
If we exceed our initial goal, and I hope we will, then we've lined up ten
manuscripts that we'd like to purchase in the coming year. (These are all digital scans, except for Pozzo which is scanned from microfilm.) Here they are with their funding thresholds:
<ul>
$1500 - Success! Server costs covered for 2015
$1600 - The Nuremberg (""Döbringer"") Hausbuch (MS. 3227a)
$1800 - Girolamo Cavalcabo's original Italian manuscript (Ms. Italien 1527)
$2100 - 1580 English translation of Paride del Pozzo (Ms. V.b.104)
$2500 - The Jud Lew manuscript (Cod. I.6.4º.3)
$3000 - Giovanni Antonio Lovino's manuscript (Ms. Italien 959)
$3700 - Angelo Viggiani's manuscript (Cod. 10723)
$4800 - Captain Peloquin's manuscript (Ms. KB.73.J.39)
$6400 - The 1443/Gotha version of Talhoffer (Ms. Chart. A. 558)
$8500 - Choose your own adventure:
• The Hague manuscript of Salvator Fabris (Ms. KB.73.J.38)
• Maister Liechtenawers Kunstbuech (Cgm 3712)
• Antonius Rast's Fechtbuch (Reichsstadt Nr. 82)
$11500 - The Copenhagen manuscript of Salvator Fabris (Ms. GKS 1868/r)

These are all important and significant treatises, but the last one is a treasure that all students of Fabris (and anyone who loves manuscripts) would love to see. The presentation copy of his famous book is a beautiful illuminated manuscript fit for a king—though it was, in fact, made for the king's cousin Duke Johan Frederik—and might also contain content not found in the printed version. Unfortunately, the Royal Library is asking a king's ransom to have it scanned, so we have to save it for last. (If we wildly exceed all expectations, the figure they quoted for archival-quality digital scans of the manuscript converts to roughly $16,000.)

We've calculated these numbers to not only cover the cost of the scans, but to also pay for the boons we're offering as well as leaving us some extra funding at the end of the day for other projects (and possibly even more wiggle room if the Euro stays depressed through the end of February, since these figures are based on the currency value at the start of the year)
column2: new manuscripts are being discovered all the time and the last thing we want is to have a pivotal treatise come to light only when we've exhausted our funds and can't bring it to the community.

column1: <div>
<h3>Risks &amp

Wiktenauer is a well-established project at this stage and has a proven track record of delivering content to the community. I've personally been organizing the purchase of manuscript scans for the community since I started the Gladiatoria Project in 2008.
The only real risk is that the libraries and museums we've contacted will fail to honor the price quotes they sent us, in which case we might come up short of money on the last purchases.
The other risk is that I could be plowed down by a bus tomorrow or killed in a blizzard in today, but in that case I hope you fine people will carry on the work in my stead.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
The fundraiser will run for three weeks, until the middle of February. If you don't have money to donate right now, we understand
column2: times are hard all around. You can still help by getting the word out and sending others our way. Post the link everywhere links get posted (like... social media... places), tell the members of your club, share it with your loved ones, and so on.

column1: And above all, keep reading and keep training. The Wiktenauer isn't an end in itself, so whether you donate or not, we hope you're making use of this resource in every way you can think of. HEMA runs on manuals, and we're just here to provide the fuel.

The Fiore books are 282 and 288 pages long (respectively) and include translations by Kendra Brown, Michael Chidester, Rebecca Garber, Colin Hatcher, and Guy Windsor—including the first-ever English translation of the Paris manuscript. Here is the description from the book jacket:""Drawing on the manuscript scans, transcriptions, and translations hosted by Wiktenauer, this book offers the first ever compilation of the four known copies of the treatise of Fiore de'i Liberi. Printed books: I will take the three e-books I just described, have them printed up in color and spiral bound (so they lay flat), and ship them out. If you get a printed book, you will also receive the e-book version for use on computers.

To be clear, these books (in digital and print form) are a repackaging of content currently on the Wiktenauer, no more, no less. The e-book you receive will match the text of the Wiktenauer articles, just organized in a way that may facilitate study (and any corrections I make in finishing the books will also be made in said articles).

Also to be clear, neither the print book nor the e-book will ever go on sale anywhere else. Wiktenauer is not, at this time, in the publishing industry and we don't have a store. The number of books we're planning to make is capped at 94, and we'll only increase that number if demand is overwhelming. If you don't pick one up in this fundraiser, you'll have to hope that we offer a similar deal next year.

My friend Mahsun Sahin in Istanbul, Turkey has found his calling to become a chef. He has found a certification program in Istanbul that would allow him to launch his career in cooking. He needs funds for tuition and to pay the rent for his apartment accommodation. For eight months, he will enroll in the Chef's Table Ascilik Okulu cooking course five days a week and learn to cook gourmet food and desserts from various world cuisines. With this certification, he will be able to find positions at 4 and 5 star establishments around the world. Any contribution is appreciated. Thank you for your support. For more information about the course, visit https://chefstable.com.tr/

","My friend Mahsun Sahin in Istanbul, Turkey has found his calling to become a chef. He has found a certification program in Istanbul that would allow him to launch his career in cooking. He needs funds for tuition and to pay the rent for his apartment accommodation. For eight months, he will enroll in the Chef's Table Ascilik Okulu cooking course five days a week and learn to cook gourmet food and desserts from various world cuisines. With this certification, he will be able to find positions at 4 and 5 star establishments around the world. Any contribution is appreciated. Thank you for your support. More than 300 people have preordered a Leka. This is just incredible!

We are so happy and thrilled, and we want to thank you again and again for your amazing support!

Leka will be shipped the second quarter of 2017. Which is one year after the pre-order campaign. This date is based on commitments we have made with our manufacturer. It will give us enough time to make sure that Leka works as smoothly as possible, is solid enough for your child, and meets all the legal &
column2: regulatory requirements.
column3:
/>

Leka is an interactive and multi-sensory smart toy, offering children with special needs the ability to play fun and educational games that motivates social interactions, that increase motor, cognitive, and emotional skills, as well as stimulates autonomy.

Based on papers published in peer reviewed sources, Leka has been developed hand-in-hand with parents, therapists and caregivers, to aid in a variety of settings. From the office, to schools, to home, Leka is making therapy easier, more efficient, and more accessible.
column5:
>FEATURES

As a robotic toy, Leka is a child’s perfect companion and friend. 

EQUIPPED WITH SENSORS

Leka can detect and respond to a child’s interaction through autonomous behaviors. Interactive responses aim to help children better understand social cues and improve their social skills. 

PREDICTABLE IN ITS INTERACTIONS (meaning, each and all of its interactions are pre-programmed)

Leka give children a sense of safety and peace of mind

A WIDE RANGE OF STIMULATIONS, FINELY CUSTOMIZABLE

Even children with restrictive areas of interest will find their own source of motivation.Because each child is unique, we made Leka's stimulations and applications finely customizable to be able to adapt to a child’s individual needs for engagement and motivation and to advance alongside each child’s progress. 

With Leka, there is finally a resource for parents who want to complement existing therapies and foster family harmony with parents and siblings through multiplayer games, both at school and at home.
column13:
/>

Leka is focused on making social interaction easier with the child's family and surroundings through multiplayer games as well as reducing anxiety and stress.
column17:
>Leka motivates and guides the child throughout the day to autonomously complete different daily tasks through pictograms displayed on its screen and vocal instructions.

 

Leka helps parents, caregivers and therapists teach motor, cognitive, and emotional skills through play. Integrating Leka at home and in school will then help parents and therapists to stay connected.

column1: <div>

Besides Leka's interactive responses, we are developing educational applications targeting the specific needs of children such as motor, cognitive, social, and emotional disorders. These applications can be used as:
<ul>
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >MULTIPLAYER ACTIVITIES – used with parents, therapists, and siblings to motivate social interactions and foster family harmony.

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >AUTONOMOUS ACTIVITIES – used to help a child play on his or her own, building a sense of independence, and control over emotions, frustration, and anxiety.

column1: Within each application users will be able to customize the level of difficulty of the application and to modify the guidance level, or how much instructions Leka needs to provide the child with in order to complete the game.
These games engage children and give them the opportunity to play and learn at the same time.
<div>

Leka’s power lies in its ability to motivate children. This is why Leka will offer 3 autonomy-building apps such as Time-Timer, Alarm Clock, and Nightlight, common assistance tools for special needs children, making children and parent’s lives easier!
[Coming in 2018]

To help parents, therapists, and caregivers work as a team towards faster progress. Leka will provide data on how the children interact with the device and allows parents to follow their children’s progress.

For example, when analyzing the raw data generated through the interaction of the child with the robot, we can understand what kind of guidance is more helpful to the child to allow him to complete the task. All of this information is displayed in graphs on the tracking tab of the monitoring platform.
From this shared interface, parents, therapists, and caregivers can communicate with each other about things like assigning homework or sharing notes on a child’s use and progress.

column2: >With this monitoring platform Leka can offer a more consistent therapy and let children achieve faster progress.

column1: <div>
<h3 style=""text-align: center
<div>

Years of research on social robotics and developmental psychology has shown the learning potential of robots for children with Autism. We have built our features based on what has been demonstrated in this field.

Subsequently, through our tests we realized this technology is not only beneficial for children with autism, but could also be an adaptable learning tool for many other children with developmental disorders.

Leka is aligned with research-based developmental milestones. Our educational applications are designed through qualitative studies, direct observation of children using Leka, and has been validated by the French Advisory &
column2: Scientific Board, an organization composed of some of France’s top researchers, therapists, caregivers, entrepreneurs and organization executives.

Which is one year after the pre-order campaign. This date is based on commitments we have made with our manufacturer. It will give us enough time to make sure that Leka works as smoothly as possible, is solid enough for your child, and meets all the legal & regulatory requirements. Leka is an interactive and multi-sensory smart toy, offering children with special needs the ability to play fun and educational games that motivates social interactions, that increase motor, cognitive, and emotional skills, as well as stimulates autonomy.Based on papers published in peer reviewed sources, Leka has been developed hand-in-hand with parents, therapists and caregivers, to aid in a variety of settings. From the office, to schools, to home, Leka is making therapy easier, more efficient, and more accessible. FEATURESAs a robotic toy, Leka is a child’s perfect companion and friend. EQUIPPED WITH SENSORSLeka can detect and respond to a child’s interaction through autonomous behaviors. Interactive responses aim to help children better understand social cues and improve their social skills. PREDICTABLE IN ITS INTERACTIONS (meaning, each and all of its interactions are pre-programmed)Leka give children a sense of safety and peace of mindA WIDE RANGE OF STIMULATIONS, FINELY CUSTOMIZABLEEven children with restrictive areas of interest will find their own source of motivation.Because each child is unique, we made Leka's stimulations and applications finely customizable to be able to adapt to a child’s individual needs for engagement and motivation and to advance alongside each child’s progress. With Leka, there is finally a resource for parents who want to complement existing therapies and foster family harmony with parents and siblings through multiplayer games, both at school and at home.LEKA'S BENEFITLeka is focused on making social interaction easier with the child's family and surroundings through multiplayer games as well as reducing anxiety and stress.   Leka motivates and guides the child throughout the day to autonomously complete different daily tasks through pictograms displayed on its screen and vocal instructions. Leka helps parents, caregivers and therapists teach motor, cognitive, and emotional skills through play. Integrating Leka at home and in school will then help parents and therapists to stay connected.

Besides Leka's interactive responses, we are developing educational applications targeting the specific needs of children such as motor, cognitive, social, and emotional disorders. These applications can be used as:
MULTIPLAYER ACTIVITIES – used with parents, therapists, and siblings to motivate social interactions and foster family harmony.
AUTONOMOUS ACTIVITIES – used to help a child play on his or her own, building a sense of independence, and control over emotions, frustration, and anxiety.

Within each application users will be able to customize the level of difficulty of the application and to modify the guidance level, or how much instructions Leka needs to provide the child with in order to complete the game.
These games engage children and give them the opportunity to play and learn at the same time.

Leka’s power lies in its ability to motivate children. This is why Leka will offer 3 autonomy-building apps such as Time-Timer, Alarm Clock, and Nightlight, common assistance tools for special needs children, making children and parent’s lives easier!
[Coming in 2018]

To help parents, therapists, and caregivers work as a team towards faster progress. Leka will provide data on how the children interact with the device and allows parents to follow their children’s progress.

For example, when analyzing the raw data generated through the interaction of the child with the robot, we can understand what kind of guidance is more helpful to the child to allow him to complete the task. All of this information is displayed in graphs on the tracking tab of the monitoring platform.
From this shared interface, parents, therapists, and caregivers can communicate with each other about things like assigning homework or sharing notes on a child’s use and progress.
With this monitoring platform Leka can offer a more consistent therapy and let children achieve faster progress.
RESEARCH-BASED & USER-CENTRIC DESIGNED

Years of research on social robotics and developmental psychology has shown the learning potential of robots for children with Autism. We have built our features based on what has been demonstrated in this field.

Subsequently, through our tests we realized this technology is not only beneficial for children with autism, but could also be an adaptable learning tool for many other children with developmental disorders.

Leka is aligned with research-based developmental milestones. Our educational applications are designed through qualitative studies, direct observation of children using Leka, and has been validated by the French Advisory & Scientific Board, an organization composed of some of France’s top researchers, therapists, caregivers, entrepreneurs and organization executives.
PARTNERS

Filmmaker and activist Tariq Nasheed is organizing the Foundational Black American Convention that will take place in Atlanta in 2020. This is a non-partisan, educational event that will feature expert panels from Black American speakers and professionals. FBAC2020 will also feature think tank forums that will brainstorm on solutions for a Foundational Black American agenda.
Some of the educational topics that will be discussed:

*Strategies on getting reparations

*Strategies on Black business developement

*Creating directories to connect with Black businesses

*Organizing retainer pools for Black lawyers

*Networking with independent Black owned schools

*Creating discussion panels with Black health professionals

*and much more.
The Organizers
Tariq Nasheed and the Melanoid Nation Foundation has a consistent track record of organizing projects and events that has influenced cultural education around the world
<h3>Risks &amp

The FBAC2020 is a 100% non-partisan endeavor. An event like this could be perceived as a challenge to entities with certain political motivations. So we have to be careful not to be swayed by potential outside agitators and saboteurs who wish to undermine a positive project of this magnitude.

Short Summary

In the Spring of 2020, after the closure of our son's childcare program, Ali decided to stay home with our son, Shamus, while Mary worked from home. To bring in some additional income, Ali began nannying several local children as needed. As word spread of this, it became clear that there is a need for quality childcare for infants and toddlers in the Peterborough, NH area. With Mary's certificate in Early Childhood Education and experience working with infants and toddlers in a Waldorf-inspired childcare, and Ali's love of cooking, gardening, and the outdoors, we felt drawn to fill this need for our community.

To this end, we plan to start up our own licensed childcare center serving Peterborough and surrounding towns, providing care for children ages 6 months to 3 years. The Little Blue House Home Childcare Center will be a Waldorf-inspired program with a strong emphasis on nature and play-based learning.
What We Need

We are looking for financial support to cover our start up costs. Childcare centers are often not profitable businesses, so it is important to us to receive community support in this venture. Starting a licensed childcare center requires inspections, fees, equipment, further education and trainings, and more. Your contribution will help in so many ways, but here are some of the things you can expect:
<ul>
• Additional outdoor fencing
• Highchairs, nap mats, cribs, changing table, and other equipment
• CPR and first aid training
• Waldorf education trainings
• Continued education credits
• Multi-seater stroller for walks with the entire group
• And more!
Other Ways You Can Help
Financial support is not the only way you can help! Here are some of the other ways you can provide support for the Little Blue House Home Childcare:
<ul>
• Donating art and craft supplies
• Lending your services (painting, carpentry, landscaping, etc.)
• Sharing this page on your own social platform to spread the word!

Kami Senang Membaca! We love to read!

Envision a space that inspires young children to become excited about reading -  freshly painted walls, a comfortable seating area, and shelves lined with engaging books for children to get lost in. With this vision in mind, the library at SD1, the public elementary school on Gili Air, could use your help! SD1 serves about 200 students from class 1-6 (ages 7-12). The school itself hasn’t changed much in 30 years and a library renovation is just what they need to bring new educational energy to their learning environment. So, together with the Kapala Desa and teachers from the school, we are working on a project to transform the current library space into a place that supports literacy as well as other learning activities.

To achieve this, we need paint supplies, two strong fans, an air conditioning unit, a large carpet, and a comfortable sofa. We are also working with locals to build custom furniture that meets the needs of the students and teachers to fully utilize the space.
Simultaneously, we are accepting book donations of high quality English texts and collecting cash donations to purchase books at the appropriate levels.

We project that the materials and furniture costs will be  $1000.  All cash donations above and beyond that will be used to purchase books and materials to make the space a vibrant learning environment.

Please consider making a donation today and know that the entirety of your generous gift will support the beautiful children of Gili Air and give the community a place to come together for educational events. Terima kasih!

Short Summary
Studio Gnome, a small business endeavor with a big mission: Nurturing joyful, creative play to promote adult wellness in thoughtful, safe, remote learning experiences.

Introducing—a summer pilot program that consists of 90-minute online classes (check out my campaign video to view a creative play class in action). Class sizes are limited to a max of 6 students so that everyone benefits from introductions, sharing perspectives, a tone-setting mindfulness practice, playful group dialog, creative activities, self-reflection, and options of performative expression.

Private and smaller group classes are also available! Play and learn with friends, partners, loved ones, and family. Speciality professional development opportunities are offered for organizations and businesses.

column3: >I'm a professional artist, grades 6-12 public school art teacher, and creative play advocate for youth and adults alike. At the age of 38, I've arrived at a point in my career where I would like to share the depths of my experiential wisdom with a wider audience. (You can find my resume at

column1: My philosophy as a professional ‘play coach’ is to gently encourage and guide participants into open-ended opportunities of playful self nurturing through practices of observation and response with themselves and the world around them. Designed to relax the logical mind, these creative practices open up a wider sense of curiosity for creative discovery
column2: similar to the mind of a child who sensitively experiments with surrounding stimuli, promoting sensory awareness. A practice in creative play build new habits of mindfulness that include a relaxed approach to our more ‘serious’ daily responsibilities. These new habits recondition the mind to approach our daily problem-solving tasks with more joyful interest and imaginative responses!

column1: “Imagination is more important than knowledge.” - Albert Einstein
What a powerful perspective by one of humanity's great minds--to solve life’s challenges with confidence in the power of the mind's imagination.
The question becomes: Are we continuing to exercise and nurture the Imagination?

Studio Gnome classes intend to foster creative exercises that break through our habitual perceptions of ‘right way’ versus ‘wrong way’ of doing things, and instead to play with refreshing ways of experiencing the mind-body connection, a world as infinitely vast as the universe itself!

Our creative capacities shape perception and the experience of life itself, with the power to transform feelings and how we move through the world. In every moment the act of 'becoming' exists, the freedom to learn new possibilities or re-learn forgotten ones. Creative confidence allows an individual to feel more in control. When facing the pressure of a deadline, for instance, learned practices of creative play can rescue us from chronic procrastination, and its inevitable downward spiral of anxiety.
We have a choice. To foster mindsets that are ready to adapt to the unexpected situations and moments life throws at us or not. A regular practice in creative play  prepares us.
Studio Gnome's creative play class methodology hopes to contribute in its own way to a transformational movement for the wellness of individuals, communities, and society at large!
Best wishes in your creative practices,
Emily Anne Hall
<h3>What We Need &amp
The monetary goal of Studio Gnome's campaign is $7,000, covering the following expenses.
<ul>
<li>

My Time: With my experience of over 20 years in the arts, including communication design and art education, I'm taking on the challenge of building this business in one summer, which includes ongoing piloted research, customized consulting, daily marketing and PR communication, backend administration, creative play teaching videos (free to the public), class preparation, and most importantly--teaching the online classes!
<li>
Marketing Expenses: Campaign costs, website hosting and add-ons
<li>
Printing Expenses of Limited Edition Art prints: Our top perks!
<li>
<strong>Supplies &amp
column2: Shipping: Art supplies such as archival watercolor and oil paint, puppet making supplies, postage and shipping materials for THANK YOU PERKS to those who have donated!

column1: <li>
Zoom Membership: Hosting for our Live creative play classes
<h3>What YOU Get: Play Class &amp

‘Thank You’ perks from campaign supporters include being part of the initial groups of participants who will experience a Studio Gnome creative play class. Other perks include limited edition art prints from my most recent paintings of 2020-2021.
$25, Three Mystery Postcard Art Prints with a written note from Emily!

$50, Group Class + Surrealist Play, an 8"" x 10"" limited edition art print. Experience one 90-minute online “Creative Play Foundations” class with 3-5 other people! A Google Form will be sent to you for scheduling. You will also be mailed an 8"" x 10"" signed limited edition of ""Surrealist Play” created by Emily during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 99 quantity run!)

A Google Form will be sent to you for scheduling. You will also be mailed an 8"" x 10"" signed limited edition of ""Raven” created by Emily during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 99 quantity run!)

$75, Group Class + Surrealist Play, an 18"" x 24"" limited edition art print. Experience one 90-minute online “Creative Play Foundations” class with 3-5 other people! A Google Form will be sent to you for scheduling. You will also be mailed an 18"" x 24"" signed limited edition of ""Surrealist Play” created by Emily during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 77 quantity run!)

$75, Group Class + Raven, an 18"" x 24"" limited edition art print. Experience one 90-minute online “Creative Play Foundations” class with 3-5 other people! A Google Form will be sent to you for scheduling. You will also be mailed an 18"" x 24"" signed limited edition of ""Raven"" created by Emily during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 77 quantity run!)

$150, PRIVATE Class + Surrealist Play, an 18"" x 24"" limited edition art print. Experience one 90-minute online “Creative Play Foundations” class with 3-5 of your family and friends!!! You will also be mailed an 18"" x 24"" signed limited edition of “Surrealist Play” created by Emily Hall during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 77 quantity run!)

$150, PRIVATE Class + Raven, an 18"" x 24"" limited edition art print. Experience one 90-minute online “Creative Play Foundations” class with with 3-5 of your family and friends!!! You will also be mailed an 18"" x 24"" signed limited edition created by Emily Hall during the summer of 2020. (First and last print of a 77 quantity run!)

$300: Triple PLAY! 3 Private Classes with Friends. Invite up to 5 friends to participate in three, 90-minute creative play classes together,... your scheduling choice! This is great for friends, families, and couples who are looking for a way to connect in a new exciting way than their usual weekly activities. Join me in the month of July, August, or the Fall season of 2021!

$500, Group OR Private Class + ""Raven"" Original Painting (16"" x 22""). You could have the original watercolor painting by Emily, one of two artworks that are headlining this campaign! Plus either a group or private creative play class experience!

$600, Group OR Private Class + ""Surrealist Play"" Original Painting (24"" x 36""). You could have the original watercolor painting by Emily, one of two artworks that are headlining this campaign! Plus either a group or private creative play class experience!

$700, Group OR Private Class + ""Playin' with the Universe"" Original (24"" x 36""). You could have this original watercolor painting by Emily that was created for my first Creative Play video!  A one and only with no printed copies. Plus either a group or private creative play class experience!

$800, Commission an Original 3' x 5’ Canvas Oil Painting (size specs are flexible and customizable) This work of art will be created during Summer of 2021.  I have sold some really beautiful oil paintings in the past above this price. With my years of experience in both design and fine art, I am confident in the creation of imaginatively stimulating compositions.
Do you like the lower tier ‘thank you’ perks instead of the one you donated for? Please send me a message to have it swapped out for a new itemized receipt!

~ Although it is my greatest hope that I reach my fundraising goal, it is important to me to ensure that the perks and tiers will still be delivered to those that support my endeavor no matter what donation amount is reached in this campaign. Please share this Indiegogo campaign's link with your friends and family to help spread the word of valuing creative play for adults. Many thanks!
Remote Creative Play Class details and scheduling:
<ul>
• Upon donating for a perk that includes a creative play class, you will be emailed with a Google Form asking about your scheduling preferences in July and August.

• Every effort will be made to accommodate participants' respective schedules, but in the event that our schedules do not align in July or August, there will be opportunities throughout the year to use your class credit.
The Impact
It has been a challenging year for all of us to find balance in our lives.

As a public school educator, I have seen various challenges faced by colleagues, parents, students, friends, and family members. We are all seeking moments of restorative joy within the day-to-day of our challenges. During my conversations with others, many people have expressed concerns about the deterioration of mental health. This may be recognized through experiences of boredom, low self-confidence, anxiety, and varying levels of depression. This can be found in our homes, our schools, our work environments, and our public spaces. People can hide it more often than not, but does it have to be this way? Do possibilities exist for developing a stronger, more confident, creative self for our own joy and to benefit those around us?

My Back Story with an Attention to Creative Play.
After a fairly straightforward and traditional art education throughout youth and high school, it was Professor Susan Zurbrigg who changed the way I see art and, ultimately, life forever.  I’d excelled in her undergraduate course at James Madison University, Drawing 101, using the visualization methods I’d used up until that point.  Seeing it in my mind, drawing it on paper or canvas.  There’s nothing wrong with this approach.  It can be effective in many contexts, but perhaps lacking in others.  The next semester, on the first day in Foundations Painting, Professor Zurbrigg stopped me:

“Emily, you’re in no way going to approach this class in the reserved, perfectionist manner you used last semester.”

I was stunned.  What did she mean?

“You’re going to leave all the baggage at the door.”

I didn’t understand.  It didn’t take long to start to learn, though.  Weeks later I stood before a giant canvas, Professor Zurbrigg encouraging me to make large sweeping marks.

“Feel the experience of painting, the process.”
“You don’t need a plan.”
“Open yourself up.”

These became like a song of mindfulness, mantras to displace me from the need to try to replicate perfection.  It was awkward for me at first.  Emptying myself of the expectations and methodology I had always relied on took time.  Months into practicing this new approach, though, of truly ridding myself of limiting mindsets—”good or bad, beautiful or ugly”—I was transformed.

The creatures that appeared on the canvas astounded me--birds with teeth, a half-dog-half-peacock flying through the night,  a one-eyed desk lamp, and others I’d never seen before!  A menagerie released from my mind and set free on canvas. It was exhilarating.  I painted more and more and by the end of the semester had my first solo exhibition at the Artful Dodger in Harrisonburg, Virginia.
My capacity to see the parts of the whole had grown. I'd learned to see the world again for the first time, as a child, the greatest gift any professor could’ve given me.
Thank you, Professor Zurbrigg.  I hope to further share the understanding you taught me.

Please check out the testimonials from friends and family who speak to the witnessing of these experiences. They can be found in my campaign video and additional videos will be added weekly with my campaign on my Studio Gnome website at www.studiognome.com.
Looking for more information behind the cause? Check out additional research about the benefits of Creative Play practices for the ever-growing adult on my website at www.studiognome.com/research.
<h3>Risks &amp

The campaign's risk is nonexistent.  All donations will receive their 'thank you' perk, regardless of the campaign's final donation amount, and I will hold creative play classes to meet interest. This said, I hope to dedicate and immerse myself full-time in further developing this pilot program as my play/work passion during summers off from teaching public school.  For this to happen, I will need to meet my campaign goal.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to monetarily donate to the mission of Studio Gnome, please know that it is still a GREAT HELP to me when you share this campaign with your friends and family. Just use the built-in Indiegogo sharing tools to send via text, email, or to your social media platforms!
THANK YOU SO MUCH.
All my care and encouragement for creative play,
Emily Anne Hall
","Short Summary
Studio Gnome, a small business endeavor with a big mission: Nurturing joyful, creative play to promote adult wellness in thoughtful, safe, remote learning experiences.

Introducing—a summer pilot program that consists of 90-minute online classes (check out my campaign video to view a creative play class in action). Class sizes are limited to a max of 6 students so that everyone benefits from introductions, sharing perspectives, a tone-setting mindfulness practice, playful group dialog, creative activities, self-reflection, and options of performative expression.

Private and smaller group classes are also available! Play and learn with friends, partners, loved ones, and family. Speciality professional development opportunities are offered for organizations and businesses.
Hello from Studio Gnome!

I'm a professional artist, grades 6-12 public school art teacher, and creative play advocate for youth and adults alike. At the age of 38, I've arrived at a point in my career where I would like to share the depths of my experiential wisdom with a wider audience. (You can find my resume at www.studiognome.com/resume)

My philosophy as a professional ‘play coach’ is to gently encourage and guide participants into open-ended opportunities of playful self nurturing through practices of observation and response with themselves and the world around them. Designed to relax the logical mind, these creative practices open up a wider sense of curiosity for creative discovery
column2: similar to the mind of a child who sensitively experiments with surrounding stimuli, promoting sensory awareness. A practice in creative play build new habits of mindfulness that include a relaxed approach to our more ‘serious’ daily responsibilities. These new habits recondition the mind to approach our daily problem-solving tasks with more joyful interest and imaginative responses!

column1: “Imagination is more important than knowledge.” - Albert Einstein
What a powerful perspective by one of humanity's great minds--to solve life’s challenges with confidence in the power of the mind's imagination.
The question becomes: Are we continuing to exercise and nurture the Imagination?

Studio Gnome classes intend to foster creative exercises that break through our habitual perceptions of ‘right way’ versus ‘wrong way’ of doing things, and instead to play with refreshing ways of experiencing the mind-body connection, a world as infinitely vast as the universe itself!

Our creative capacities shape perception and the experience of life itself, with the power to transform feelings and how we move through the world. In every moment the act of 'becoming' exists, the freedom to learn new possibilities or re-learn forgotten ones. Creative confidence allows an individual to feel more in control. When facing the pressure of a deadline, for instance, learned practices of creative play can rescue us from chronic procrastination, and its inevitable downward spiral of anxiety.
We have a choice. To foster mindsets that are ready to adapt to the unexpected situations and moments life throws at us or not. A regular practice in creative play  prepares us.
Studio Gnome's creative play class methodology hopes to contribute in its own way to a transformational movement for the wellness of individuals, communities, and society at large!
Best wishes in your creative practices,
Emily Anne Hall
What We Need & Why
The monetary goal of Studio Gnome's campaign is $7,000, covering the following expenses.

My Time: With my experience of over 20 years in the arts, including communication design and art education, I'm taking on the challenge of building this business in one summer, which includes ongoing piloted research, customized consulting, daily marketing and PR communication, backend administration, creative play teaching videos (free to the public), class preparation, and most importantly--teaching the online classes!

The Impact
It has been a challenging year for all of us to find balance in our lives.

As a public school educator, I have seen various challenges faced by colleagues, parents, students, friends, and family members. We are all seeking moments of restorative joy within the day-to-day of our challenges. During my conversations with others, many people have expressed concerns about the deterioration of mental health. This may be recognized through experiences of boredom, low self-confidence, anxiety, and varying levels of depression. This can be found in our homes, our schools, our work environments, and our public spaces. People can hide it more often than not, but does it have to be this way? Do possibilities exist for developing a stronger, more confident, creative self for our own joy and to benefit those around us?

My Back Story with an Attention to Creative Play.After a fairly straightforward and traditional art education throughout youth and high school, it was Professor Susan Zurbrigg who changed the way I see art and, ultimately, life forever.  I’d excelled in her undergraduate course at James Madison University, Drawing 101, using the visualization methods I’d used up until that point.  Seeing it in my mind, drawing it on paper or canvas.  There’s nothing wrong with this approach.  It can be effective in many contexts, but perhaps lacking in others.  The next semester, on the first day in Foundations Painting, Professor Zurbrigg stopped me:“Emily, you’re in no way going to approach this class in the reserved, perfectionist manner you used last semester.”I was stunned.  What did she mean?“You’re going to leave all the baggage at the door.”I didn’t understand.  It didn’t take long to start to learn, though.  Weeks later I stood before a giant canvas, Professor Zurbrigg encouraging me to make large sweeping marks.“Feel the experience of painting, the process.”
“You don’t need a plan.”
“Open yourself up.”

These became like a song of mindfulness, mantras to displace me from the need to try to replicate perfection.  It was awkward for me at first.  Emptying myself of the expectations and methodology I had always relied on took time.  Months into practicing this new approach, though, of truly ridding myself of limiting mindsets—”good or bad, beautiful or ugly”—I was transformed.The creatures that appeared on the canvas astounded me--birds with teeth, a half-dog-half-peacock flying through the night,  a one-eyed desk lamp, and others I’d never seen before!  A menagerie released from my mind and set free on canvas. It was exhilarating.  I painted more and more and by the end of the semester had my first solo exhibition at the Artful Dodger in Harrisonburg, Virginia.
My capacity to see the parts of the whole had grown. I'd learned to see the world again for the first time, as a child, the greatest gift any professor could’ve given me.
Thank you, Professor Zurbrigg.  I hope to further share the understanding you taught me.

Please check out the testimonials from friends and family who speak to the witnessing of these experiences. They can be found in my campaign video and additional videos will be added weekly with my campaign on my Studio Gnome website at www.studiognome.com.
Looking for more information behind the cause? Check out additional research about the benefits of Creative Play practices for the ever-growing adult on my website at www.studiognome.com/research.
Risks & Challenges

The campaign's risk is nonexistent.  All donations will receive their 'thank you' perk, regardless of the campaign's final donation amount, and I will hold creative play classes to meet interest. This said, I hope to dedicate and immerse myself full-time in further developing this pilot program as my play/work passion during summers off from teaching public school.  For this to happen, I will need to meet my campaign goal.

Learning Japanese? 

Enough learning, let's start Speaking!

 

 

Aomi Japanese. Speaking

Is the 1st app that is training you HOW to speak at the same time providing you with useful language patterns to boost your conversation skills.

Aomi Japanese.Speaking  gives you Speaking ""workouts"" by imitating linguistic environment and allowing you to listen to native speakers and repeat after them.

 

 

Practice Speaking in 3 simple steps!

 

 

 

Our Technology
column3:
showinfo=0"">

 

 

 

What do you find inside Trainings:

 

 

 

How does it work?

 

 

To be able to speak the language is to be able to know what to say, when to say it and how to say it. More precisely, it means to be able to quickly recall necessary language patterns and  pronounce them in the way that native speakers can understand. 

 

1. Language Patterns

For almost every situation, every language has its own phrases - ""language patterns"".This is how native speakers speak in everyday life. Japanese language is no exception!  Knowing these patterns will make your speech sound natural.

 

2. Pitch Patterns

Japanese is a musical language. Unlike English, where words have  stress-accent, Japanese words have a pitch-accent, where by decreasing or increasing your tone you can put accent in words.


The intonation of the entire phrase, which changes according to the pitch-accent in the words is called a ""pitch pattern"". Not paying attention to your pitch-pattern can make it hard for native speakers to understand you. By applying right pitch patterns to your speech, you will sound natural and easy to comprehend even from the very early stage of your learning.

We know that being able to recall words and phrases and be able to pronounce them properly takes time as it takes time for our brains to build new pathways. Only repetition can strengthen them.

With our Trainings you get to practice several skills at once and bring them to automation. 

 

 

 

Why is it better than multilingual language apps?

Don't get us wrong! Multilingual apps are amazing when it comes to starting to learn new language. They can give you the important basics in a simple format.

However, each language is unique and same rules can't be applied to all, especially if you are progressing in your learning process.

To be able to really Speak Japanese language you need to enrich your vocabulary with language patterns that are particular to this language. You need to get familiar with various conversational contexts and, sometimes, even with their cultural aspects. You need to understand how the language sounds and how those sounds are formed.

It requires time and a lot of expertise to produce this kind of content. And we are proud to say that we put our hearts and minds into producing high quality useful product. 

We believe focusing on 1 language is our greatest advantage!

 

For those who wants to study Japanese language in-depth ♥

 

 

 

PROGRESS &
column4:
TEAM

APP REALEASE: SEPTEMBER 2021

 

Currently, we are almost finishing our development process and are expecting to deliver our app in the beginning of September 2021.

We are also looking for people who would like to take part in the early testing community to help us make the product that truly meets the needs.

Even if you are unable or not ready to contribute financially as of now, just spreading the word about us on social media will do a lot.  We appreciate your interest in our success ♥

You can also check our webpage and leave your e-mail so that you'll be the first one to know when the App is released. 

And if you want to contribute at a Sponsor level, we will be honored to mention you as one of our ""Founding"" brothers or sisters on our webpage. To rephrase a saying: It takes people to build a good product. We do believe it. 

 

Team

Our team consists of active learners of Japanese language at different stages, so we know all the pains of the process and always consider how it can be improved and designed better. At the same time, professional educator, native speaker and PhD in Philological Sciences on our team help us to carefully select and produce a unique high-quality content that can be really useful even for native speakers. 

 

We strongly believe that to make such a difficult language as Japanese attractive to more people we need to make the process of learning modern, fun and effective first. And what’s more, for those who are already learning this language we want to improve their experience so that they stay committed to their dream of speaking Japanese and being able to communicate freely in it.

 

""New language is more than just a tool, it is a philosophy, a new way of looking at ordinary things"" ♥

Our Story

More than 130 million girls worldwide were out of school even before Covid-19 hit. 15 million girls of primary-school age will never enter a classroom. And over 11 million girls may not go back to school after the pandemic. The Covid-19 crisis has exacerbated the education and digital divide, magnifying inequality like never before and putting millions of girls at risk of sexual exploitation. They could become techpreneurs, scientists, innovators – but instead, they’re paying the price of this crisis with their future. 

XOCO is on fire to change the game for girls. 

We’re a non-profit edtech venture empowering adolescent girls to leapfrog from basic education to digital jobs of the future.

In partnership with grassroots organizations and the world’s most innovative companies, we’re developing a powerful digital education model to create new pathways from basic education to skilled jobs in the digital economy. 

We’re a global team of impact investors, tech geeks, digital leaders, education ninjas and entrepreneurs leveraging our networks to develop a digital education model that will bring world-class business education to young women with low levels of formal education.

The objective of this crowdfunding campaign is to launch XOCO Leapfrogging Academy – a global accelerator for adolescent girls and young women, preparing them for futuristic jobs in the digital economy.
Our Digital Education Model
Our digital education model covers world-class online training in the following areas:
<li>
<strong>Empowerment &amp
column2:
A Digital Mindset
Anything from self-esteem and goal setting to team work, communication, problem solving and digital leadership.

column1: <li>

Digital Skills
From the most basic skills like logic and math to G-suite and social media management, all the way to coding and big data.
<li>

Agile Collaboration
From new ways of collaboration like design thinking, scrum and design sprint to agile collaboration tools like Miro, Mural, Jira, Kahoot! and Padlet.
<li>
<strong>Entrepreneurship, Business &amp
column2:
Finance
Whatever you learn in business studies and actually need in the real world of business.

column1: <li>
<strong>Social &amp
column2:
Market Research
Practical training in qualitative and quantitative research, including innovative participatory methods

column1:
XOCO Leapfrogging Academy is an accelerator program to prepare adolescent girls and young women for future jobs in the digital economy. The accelerator starts with a summer school and continues with an on-going digital education program broken down into multiple 3-month sprints. Leveraging gamification, the main program allows participants to reach different levels and focuses on the range of horizontal skills relevant to succeed in the digital economy of the future. Complementary side tracks offer opportunities for specialization.

Key features of the program include the following:
<li>
Live digital classes delivered by business professionals working for local and global companies that are champions in digital transformation, agile collaboration and innovation
• Digital mentoring program with role models in the digital economy
• Peer-to-peer empowerment sprints
<li>
Collaboration on business projects to build a track record and co-develop solutions to real world challenges
• Being part of a global business network and a community of game changers for life
What We Need &

Our Fundraising Goal

Our initial fundraising goal is € 50K to kickstart our pilot projects. Our own team is contributing an additional € 50K in-kind. We’re already all-in for this venture. But we can’t make this happen without your financial support. 

Latin America Pilots:

Our LatAm pilots will be rolled out in collaboration with our local partner organizations MDYM Colombia and Care Ecuador. We will launch XOCO Leapfrogging Academy with the first cohort of vulnerable adolescent girls in our pilot countries Colombia and Ecuador. Girls participating in our pilots are those hit hardest by the Covid-19 crisis and who need an urgent way out of situations of gender-based violence. The contribution you make will pay for their stipend (food, shelter, health insurance, digital access), so they can fully focus on their education at XOCO Leapfrogging Academy and are no longer at risk of sexual exploitation due to the economic crisis. The € 50K funding will allow us to launch the Colombia pilot and aims to crowd in additional funding for the Ecuador pilot. 

Global Pilot:

In addition, we will run a global pilot focusing on vulnerable adolescent girls across the global South who will have the opportunity to join our XOCO Leapfrogging Academy programs for free, but do not need a full-fledged stipend. 

The contribution our team makes is in-kind valued at 50K € (in 2021) and will cover the full accelerator program, including course development, live classes delivered by business professionals, our mentoring program connecting participants with role models, and collaboration with companies on real world projects. 

Our initial pilot projects are key to reach proof of concept stage and then scale.
The € 50K target will allow us to reach 50 vulnerable adolescent girls participating in our LatAm and global pilot accelerator programs in the first year. This will allow us to get ready to scale up exponentially in the second and third year.  

If we don’t reach the entire fundraising goal, we can still do smaller pilots and flexibly adjust. However, the more we raise, the more girls we can empower and the faster we can grow our global accelerator programs. For every additional € 20K raised, we will start another cohort of girls who participate in our accelerator program.
Our Perks for You

We’ve mobilized our collective superpowers to bring you the most exciting perks!

Please note: XOCO is a non-profit organization, so your contributions are a donation. As a special thank-you for your donation, we are offering exciting perks provided pro-bono by our network. 

Boosting Your Visibility
• A range of perks from a simple Instagram shout-out to getting featured in XOCO’s Podcast
• Networking opportunities to connect with entrepreneurs, investors and change makers from around the world
Future of Impact Summit 2021

• XOCO’s Future of Impact Summit 2021 brings together impact-driven entrepreneurs, investors, digital leaders, empowerment champions, policy makers, and ecosystem players to connect, learn and inspire action towards an equitable, inclusive and sustainable recovery on the journey to the SDGs 2030.
• Join us for a lively and action-driven 5-day virtual Summit.
• Check out the full program on our events page.
Summit Special Packages:
• Join our special tracks: 1) Entrepreneurship, 2) Investors, 3) Agile SuperPower
• On top of VIP access to all Summit sessions over 5 days, get strategically matched to business partners and invited to exclusive pre-and post-Summit special sessions, tailored to your objectives.
Be a Partner @ the Summit
• Shape a session with us at the Summit!
• To discuss details, get in touch!

XOCO SuperHero All-In

You’re all in – we love it! With this package, you get absolutely everything:
• Breakfast with the XOCO team to contribute ideas, ask questions and get inspired
• Be a VIP at our 5-day global Future of Impact Summit (virtual)
<li>Get featured in XOCO’s Podcast (meet &amp
• Xocer@ Status for 12 months: Get VIP access to XOCO Insights, our digital platform delivering impact research, practitioner tools and behind-the-scenes insights
• VIP invitation to XOCO’s Annual Gala (virtual)
<li>Tell us how we can help you reach your goals &amp

column1: The Impact
Since its advent, the COVID-19 pandemic has been a disaster for girls
column2:
pulling them out of education and pushing them into sexual exploitation. Given the unprecedented speed of this occurrence, it has quickly become evident that we have to be faster, bolder and more innovative in our response. We launched XOCO in 2020 as an unconventional edtech venture to change the game for girls.

We are on fire to connect the dots and build innovative partnerships, co-creating new solutions to bridge the digital divide and the equity gap in education. 

The impact of our Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign will be catalytic: It will enable us to pilot and refine our model with parallel pilot cohorts across Latin America, Africa and Asia. This will lead us to the milestone of proof-of-concept and subsequently allow us to scale our model exponentially.

column1: Risks &

Our greatest risk is fundraising in the startup phase. The fundraising risk is closely related to our biggest challenge: Balancing depth of impact with scale of impact.

In this pilot phase, we have a strong focus on depth of impact. This means we focus on the most vulnerable adolescent girls in the global South and we accompany them on their education journey with a very intensive and holistic long-term model, so we can be sure that they actually and sustainably escape gender-based violence and leapfrog to digital jobs of the future.
<li>Our Latin America pilot focuses on girls who are caught up in complicated situations of sexual exploitation. Our digital education &amp
column2: empowerment program is their way out. Many of them have babies and are homeless. Given the complexity of the challenge, our holistic empowerment model is resource intensive: In Colombia, we provide a full-fledged shelter solution and empowerment support in addition to our digital education program to catch up with basic education and prepare them for the digital jobs of the future.

column1: • Our Global pilot takes a more prevention-oriented approach, focusing on adolescent girls at high risk of gender-based violence. Our digital education program empowers them to navigate these risks, cope with the unprecedented challenges of the pandemic and continue their education journey, completing high school while joining our global accelerator program.

Depth of impact is important for this first phase of our venture in order to co-create an innovative education model that delivers on the envisioned impact goals. Once we have a tested and proven solution, we will scale it through partnerships, placing greater emphasis on the scale of impact. 

XOCO recently became a fellow of Columbia e-Lab designed to bring together a selected cohort of the best 25 edtech &
column2: reskilling startup founders from around the world. This peer learning community allows us to share knowledge and learnings, challenges and solutions, with other leading edtech entrepreneurs. This network will be a great resource and help us turn these challenges into opportunities.
