. : About Westchase Tutoring

Hi, I'm Cyprus Walter, and I founded Westchase Tutoring in order to serve my community in the way I know best: as an educator.

For the past 4 1/2 years, I've been working as a high school teacher, and while the experience completely humbled and changed me, I felt limited in my capacity to impact lives.

As someone who has tutored before, I know the power of individual education, which is something that a lot of students don't have access to.

Even with the world’s greatest teachers, sometimes students have that the classroom environment can’t provide.

That's where Westchase Tutoring comes in. 

My vision is to provide a world-class service that not only assists with academic subjects, but also cultivates sound study habits, responsibility, and independence.

. : Our Goals &
column2:
Vision

Our fundraising goal is $2,200, which breaks down into the following categories:

Promo/Marketing: $750.00

Office Supplies: $500.00

Travel: $350.00

Professional Website (for one year): $250.00

Professional Services (business consultation, legal advice, etc.): $350.00

With these funds, we can focus our time on continuing to develop a relationship with the schools in our community.

These numbers reflect an estimation of the most basic startup expenses for our endeavor.

After we launch, the business should take care of itself!

Should we fail to reach our goal, we will still use whatever funds we've received to push the business forward.

By helping us raise capital, you're freeing us up to put more time into people.

. : The End in Mind

Although certainly qualified to teach a multitude of content areas, it’s my ability to read people and assess not only their learning needs but also who they are as people that I believe gives me an edge as a tutor.

Something really clicks when I have the opportunity to witness the personal growth of my clients.

I've got these young adults, confident but not quite sure how to show it at first, who really hit their stride right before my eyes.

It’s in that moment, when the light bulb goes off, when I feel like their success in life is my success, and that’s when I know I’m a part of something greater than myself.

. : The Road Ahead

The most challenging part of lauching this business is going to be the procurement of new clients.

Earning people's trust takes time.

With the help of outside funding, I'll be free to build that trust by getting out into the community and working with local educators to assess the needs within their schools.

I hope today we've earned your trust and support.

If you're behind us, then feel free to donate an amount you are comfortable with--it all adds up.

And above all else... Help us get the word out!

Share on Facebook, other social media, and even use Indiegogo to spread the news.

Thank you!

--Cyprus

Freddie Gray was only 25 when he was murdered. He was chased, beaten, and arrested for ""making eye contact"" with Baltimore Police officers on April 12th, resulting in his voice box being crushed and his spine being severed from his body. On April 19th, he died due to spinal injuries sustained in the beating.

Baltimore has been in uprising, demanding justice and calling for the end of police brutality and #every28hrs.

As a form of solidarity, BlackLivesMatter Toronto is crowd funding to send funds to Baltimore. These funds will go to grass roots organizing supporting the most vulnerable segments of our population affected on the ground in Baltimore. We are sending funding to Baltimore local organizations and projects listed below:

Free State Legal

Transgender Action Group

Speak Fire

Star Track

If you are in a position to do so, please donate generously. If you do not have paypal or e-banking, please bring disposable funds to donate at the rally May 2nd.

https://www.facebook.com/events/1434790026817929/

#BLACKLIVESMATTER #TDOT2BMORE #BLMTO #BaltimoreUprising

Why do transgender and gender diverse youth need haircuts?
<div style=""text-align: center
<ul>
<li>
It is estimated that at least 1 in 1,000 Australians are transgender and recent research shows that 2-4% of young people are gender diverse. At least 50% of
transgender Australians experience depression and anxiety.
<li>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Transgender people and people of
column4: > may be the only person in their school or family who identify differently, which can cause feelings of isolation and a lack of opportunities.

column1: • Younger people may not have the money or the personal support to get a gender-affirming haircut for themselves.

• I am incredibly excited to partner with Razor Dolls (Chapel Street, Windsor, VIC) to hold a day of free haircuts for transgender and gender diverse youth. Their talented staff are very generously holding an extra day of business in December 2015 for this event.
What We Need
<li>
$350 will cover the basic costs of this event.
column2: > 24 people will get a brand new hairdo - one that best reflects their desired presentation in align with their gender identity. All staff and clients will be supplied with a name &amp
column5: > sticker to avoid being misgendered or mis-pronouned.

column1: • This event is about more than just haircuts. It will provide an opportunity for transgender and gender diverse youth to spend an afternoon together, sharing experiences and finding a sense of community within their peer group.
• A $750 total raised will help provide food and drinks for clients to enjoy with each other, and hair goodies to use on the day - glitter, coloured hair chalk, hair clips and ties!
• A $1,000+ total will cover all of the above, plus the costs of cosmetics so clients can choose to get their nails painted, a temporary tattoo, or a mini eye makeover.
<li>
Indiegogo includes shipping costs in the total amount raised, so $1,000 for our event will look more like $1,200 - 1,300 raised.
<li>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >We want this event to be as big, beautiful, empowering and enjoyable as possible, and hope all money raised can go towards that. If any funds are left over they will be donated to Australian mental health and LGBTQIA+ charity organisations, such as Headspace.

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Please remember that Indiegogo takes a 5% fee from the total raised, and Paypal processing and currency conversion also charges 3-5%.

column1: What You Get
<div>
<ul>
• You can help make this happen. Check under your couch cushions, you might find some loose change - or at least an old potato chip.
• If you are able give more than a gold coin, we are very excited to collaborate with several independent artists and small business owners to offer some incredible perks in reward for donating.
Why This Cause?
<div style=""text-align: left

• As a twenty-four year old non-binary Melbournian, I recently chose the Razor Dolls salon for my own gender-affirming haircut. A new hairstyle has greatly improved my confidence and helped to ease my uncomfortable feelings of gender dysphoria. I'm a lot happier looking in the mirror lately, and I want to make that feeling possible for others.
<div style=""text-align: centre

Keep in touch?

  • If you or someone you know aged 14-21 is interested in a free gender-affirming haircut, please sign up to our mailing list here.
• We look forward to updating you all on the success of this event. Please 'like' our Facebook Page.

Contact us

  • Twitter: @trimstransplus
• Email: trimsfortransplus@gmail.com
• View Razor Dolls' work on Instagram: @razordolls
","Why do transgender and gender diverse youth need haircuts?
It is estimated that at least 1 in 1,000 Australians are transgender and recent research shows that 2-4% of young people are gender diverse. At least 50% of
transgender Australians experience depression and anxiety.
Transgender people and people of gender minorities may be the only person in their school or family who identify differently, which can cause feelings of isolation and a lack of opportunities.
Younger people may not have the money or the personal support to get a gender-affirming haircut for themselves.

I am incredibly excited to partner with Razor Dolls (Chapel Street, Windsor, VIC) to hold a day of free haircuts for transgender and gender diverse youth. Their talented staff are very generously holding an extra day of business in December 2015 for this event.
What We Need

$350 will cover the basic costs of this event. 24 people will get a brand new hairdo - one that best reflects their desired presentation in align with their gender identity. All staff and clients will be supplied with a name & pronoun sticker to avoid being misgendered or mis-pronouned.

This event is about more than just haircuts. It will provide an opportunity for transgender and gender diverse youth to spend an afternoon together, sharing experiences and finding a sense of community within their peer group.
A $750 total raised will help provide food and drinks for clients to enjoy with each other, and hair goodies to use on the day - glitter, coloured hair chalk, hair clips and ties!
A $1,000+ total will cover all of the above, plus the costs of cosmetics so clients can choose to get their nails painted, a temporary tattoo, or a mini eye makeover.
Indiegogo includes shipping costs in the total amount raised, so $1,000 for our event will look more like $1,200 - 1,300 raised.

We want this event to be as big, beautiful, empowering and enjoyable as possible, and hope all money raised can go towards that. If any funds are left over they will be donated to Australian mental health and LGBTQIA+ charity organisations, such as Headspace.
Please remember that Indiegogo takes a 5% fee from the total raised, and Paypal processing and currency conversion also charges 3-5%.
What You Get
You can help make this happen. Check under your couch cushions, you might find some loose change - or at least an old potato chip.
If you are able give more than a gold coin, we are very excited to collaborate with several independent artists and small business owners to offer some incredible perks in reward for donating.
Why This Cause?

As a twenty-four year old non-binary Melbournian, I recently chose the Razor Dolls salon for my own gender-affirming haircut. A new hairstyle has greatly improved my confidence and helped to ease my uncomfortable feelings of gender dysphoria. I'm a lot happier looking in the mirror lately, and I want to make that feeling possible for others.
Keep in touch?  If you or someone you know aged 14-21 is interested in a free gender-affirming haircut, please sign up to our mailing list here.
We look forward to updating you all on the success of this event. Please 'like' our Facebook Page.
Contact us  Twitter: @trimstransplus
Email: trimsfortransplus@gmail.com
View Razor Dolls' work on Instagram: @razordolls",2.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Melbourne, Australia",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/free-haircuts-for-trans-gender-diverse-youth/pica

Who We Are 

COR Music Project, or The Cincinnati Outreach Music Project, is an educational school and community outreach program aimed at promoting diversity in classical music by providing high quality music instruction to youth in Cincinnati while eliminating obstacles related to access and affordability.

Mission-Focused. Our mission is to use music as a vehicle for social change by providing world-class music instruction to Cincinnati’s youth. COR Music Project eliminates obstacles related to both the access and affordability of classical music instruction, and focuses on the inclusion of all youth, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds in classical music. We aim to shape a positive future for our students and to create a feeder relationship into current Cincinnati arts organizations in order to ensure diversity and excellence for the future of music.

Visionary. We envision a world in which world-class music education is accessible to youth of all social and economic backgrounds and where the diversity of our communities is reflected within the arts.

A Philosophy that Works!  Cincinnati is an incredibly diverse community with a strong classical music culture. Unfortunately, Cincinnati’s rich diversity is not reflected within its classic musical culture. At COR, we see this lack of diversity as a vital need for increased access and affordability of music education programs for youth. These needs shape our mission and our philosophy: ALL Play, NONE Pay. What do we mean by this? Access and Affordability for All children. By eliminating the obstacles of access and affordability we are able obtain our vision.

Impact

To carry out our Mission and Vision, the leaders of COR Music Project have developed two unique approaches:  

Eliminate the Access Obstacle.  To address the need of access, COR Music Project partners with local schools lacking the resources necessary to provide fully functional music programs. COR works directly with the administration of each partner school to develop strategies that promote sustainability and build traditions among parents, teachers, students, and the surrounding community. When more students are granted access to music instruction our communities are enriched and diversity within the arts increases.

Eliminate the Affordability Obstacle. To address the need of affordability, COR Music Project partners with local community centers to build orchestras inspired by the successful “El Sistema” model. Group music instruction is offered to at-risk, elementary aged students after school for five days a week. Students are provided with music instruments and world-class music instruction at no out-of-pocket expense to them. Without cost as a deterrent, the opportunity for diversity and inclusion in music education becomes a reality.

How Can I Help? 

Brand Ambassador. Become a Brand Ambassador for COR by spreading the word through your social media network that quality music education should be available to all children regardless of socioeconomic background.  

Donate. Beyond donating your time as a Brand Ambassador consider donating financially and encouraging others to do so to help support and perpetuate our in school and after school music education programs like the Avondale Youth Orchestra and choir, Avondale Sings.

These needs shape our mission and our philosophy: ALL Play, NONE Pay. What do we mean by this? Access and Affordability for All children. By eliminating the obstacles of access and affordability we are able obtain our vision.ImpactTo carry out our Mission and Vision, the leaders of COR Music Project have developed two unique approaches:  Eliminate the Access Obstacle.  To address the need of access, COR Music Project partners with local schools lacking the resources necessary to provide fully functional music programs. COR works directly with the administration of each partner school to develop strategies that promote sustainability and build traditions among parents, teachers, students, and the surrounding community. When more students are granted access to music instruction our communities are enriched and diversity within the arts increases.Eliminate the Affordability Obstacle. To address the need of affordability, COR Music Project partners with local community centers to build orchestras inspired by the successful “El Sistema” model. Group music instruction is offered to at-risk, elementary aged students after school for five days a week. Students are provided with music instruments and world-class music instruction at no out-of-pocket expense to them. Without cost as a deterrent, the opportunity for diversity and inclusion in music education becomes a reality.How Can I Help? Brand Ambassador. Become a Brand Ambassador for COR by spreading the word through your social media network that quality music education should be available to all children regardless of socioeconomic background.  Donate. Beyond donating your time as a Brand Ambassador consider donating financially and encouraging others to do so to help support and perpetuate our in school and after school music education programs like the Avondale Youth Orchestra and choir, Avondale Sings.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Cin, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/music-education-for-all-children--2/pica

The first ‘Stories of Strength’ coloring book is
underway and we need your help getting it printed. Support this project and
help kids in the developing world get a chance to learn and color their heroes
in the bible! It might be the FIRST coloring book they ever own.
My name is Gia-YaeJi Park and I’m an artist/illustrator.
Recently I created a coloring book called ‘Stories of Strength’.  What started as small
doodles and ideas about inspiring characters in the Bible turned into a full
children’s coloring book for boys and girls.
When I went on a mission trip to Haiti, I met many talented and artistic
kids and my goal has been to educate the kids in poverty and to give them a chance
to learn and enjoy art. I wanted to teach them about colors and know that
anyone can do art. Their circumstances and background might not be in the perfect
situation for them to be artists, but anyone in the world deserve to discover

their own creative outlet.

Initially the characters I thought of making illustrations of were the more
common ones that everyone knows about, and it didn’t have many women to look up
to.  I wanted to make sure that the
children know that strength came from both men and women, especially in nations
where this is not a common case. I wanted little girls to know that they can
aspire to great things just like these women of the bible.
Through this project, each kid will receive their own coloring book with
colored pencils. Many of them never owned a coloring book in their lives, so
this will be a very special gift for them. We are trying to broaden our reach
to a diverse audience of eager children. By supporting this book project,
you’ll be supporting these goals as well.
We need to raise $5,000 to print 1,000 coloring books. These books will be
sent to Mexico, Haiti, and Dominican Republic. Everything will be translated in

their languages.

The coloring book includes not only coloring pages of biblical characters,

but also puzzle games, and basic knowledge of color theories.

We’re offering many ways in which you can invest in this project. Have a
look and thanks so much for taking part!
If you’re not able to fund this project at the moment but want to help
anyway, please share this campaign with everyone you know! Let every art-lover,
artist, parent and educator know about this exciting project. Help us make some
noise!

The Cojolya Association's Story

Founded in 1983, the Cojolya Association of Mayan Women Weavers is an NGO located in Santiago Atitlan, Guatemala, a Tz'utujil Maya community on the shores of Lake Atitlan. Certified by the World Fair Trade Organization (WFTO), we work to preserve the ancient Mayan art of backstrap weaving as a culturally and economically viable enterprise for the women who weave. We merge traditional weaving techniques with contemporary design to create beautiful textile products with a conscience. Cojolya is committed to the health and well-being of our community. Our weavers earn a fair living wage and recieve professional development training, design services, materials, and access to an international marketplace of buyers. In addition, Cojolya runs the Cojolya Social ONIL Sustainiable Stove Project, which seeks to install safe cookstoves in the homes of our community members to avoid the health and environmental problems associated with cooking over an open fire. Through gaining access to a steady, separate income source, our weavers become breadwinners for their families and gain increased power and independence to fight the marginalization that many Mayan women face. To learn more, visit us at www.cojolya.org, add us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/Cojolya, or follow us on Twitter at @Cojolya.
Holiday Visit to the Ixchel Museum

The holidays are a time of celebration and family in Santiago Atitlan. To this end, each year the Cojolya Association brings together its family of artisans  to celebrate the past year. As an organization, we strive to make sure that our talented weavers are recognized for their expertise on the loom, and that they recieve the respect they deserve as artisans. A trip to the Ixchel Museum of Indigenous Clothing and Textiles in Guatemala City will allow our weavers to see their weaving tradition showcased in one of the most famous museums in Guatemala. In addition, since many of our professional development sessions in the past several years have focused on teaching our weavers techniques native to other regions of Guatemala, a trip to the Ixchel Museum will allow our artisans to be educated and inspired by Guatemala's many non-Tz'utujil textile arts.
For rural Mayan women, access to Guatemala City's museums is barred. For most of Cojolya's weavers, few of whom speak Spanish,
the opportunity to visit the capital city comes very infrequently, if ever. To
get to and from the capital one has travel eight hours, which leaves very
little time in the city to complete necessary errands. The Museo Ixchel lies
outside of city bus lines, requiring a taxi to get there. Most importantly,
most Mayan weavers do not even know about the museum -- its focus is on
international tourism and is patronized by Guatemala's upper class. <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)

column5: >Famous anthropological and cultural museums are not often visited by the people

column1: whose history is portrayed within.  In this case, the Mayan women whose
exquisite weaving skills are exhibited may sell their textiles outside on the
street, but they would almost never have extra money to spend on the entrance
fee. This is why the opportunity to visit the Museo Ixchel and see for
themselves how their own skills have been raised upon a pedestal for all the
world to appreciate, is a huge boost to their self-esteem.  We hope that
this type of experience will encourage them to cherish their tradition and work
to preserve it, as is the mission of the Cojolya Associaton of Maya Women
Weavers.
Help the Cojolya Association thank our weavers for their hard work this holiday season by donating to our Ixchel Museum field trip!

We Need Your Help

Here's what we're raising money for:

• $400 will pay the $10 per person museum admission fee for each of our 30 artisans, plus up to ten family members and volunteers.
  • $200 will pay for three round-trip shuttles to transport our artisans and volunteers from Santiago Atitlan to Guatemala City.
  • $350 will pay for a day's worth of meals and snacks for our artisans.
• Even if we don't reach our Indiegogo fundraising goal, all funds raised will go toward the museum visit.

Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, we understand! You can still help us by:
<ul>
• Share our campaign on social media. Let your friends and family know!
• Check out our website to learn more about the Cojolya Association, and share our online marketplace of fair trade products with your friends.

The Cojolya Association of Maya Women Weavers greatly appreciates your contributions and support, which have allowed us to provide employment and social programs for 30 artisans in Santiago Atitlan and will help us to offer a meaningful visit to the Ixchel Museum this holiday season. Thank you! 

Questions? Send us an email at cojolya@cojolya.org

A Little about me and the trip

Hello!  My name is Elizabeth and I am a super awesome, intelligent, and amazing (at least that's what people tell me, wink wink) Mercy College of Ohio Nursing Student.  I have been given the distinctive opportunity to travel to Antigua, Guatemala through school (during Spring Break) to be of service to children with severe physical and/or mental disabilities living in the Santo Hermano Pedro Long-Term Care Facility.  I am grateful to have been chosen and think the children of Santo Hermano Pedro have so much to teach me. I hope to gain a great deal of insight while in Guatemala, as well as enhance my nursing skills, enabling me to blossom into the caring, compassionate, and competent Nurse I strive towards everyday!
Here is a link to the program: http://preciousbloodsistersdayton.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/mercy-college-students-travel-to-guatemala.pdf
What I Need &
column2:
What You Get

I need to pay the following expenses within the next month's time:

column1: • $1200 for the 8-week coursework prior to the trip
• $800 for round-trip airfare and transportation to Antigua, Guatemala

• $500 for food, travel, and experiences while in Guatemala
  • Any funds I receive will go directly to the course and trip
For your support in helping to fund my trip, you will receive one or all of the following:
• for a contribution of $10 or more, you will receive a hand-written ""thank you"" note with one-of-a kind drawing by, the one and only, Finley A.
• for a contribution of $50 or more, you will receive a righteous (but small) souvenir hand-selected by me from beautiful Guatemala
• for a contribution of $100 or more, you will receive a totally righteous (and slightly larger) souvenir also hand-selected by me
• best part is EVERYONE who contributes will receive my eternal gratitude!

The Impact

This trip will have a major positive impact on my future nursing career and help me stand out in a sea of job applicants while also helping me grow as a citizen of the world.  It will also benefit my long-term goal of applying for a position on a surgical team providing reconstructive surgeries to people with burn contractures living in developing countries when I have more working experience under my belt.
<ul>

• Though the trip means being away from my family for a week, I know they are just as committed to helping make the world a better place as I am and I can not express enough how much I appreciate their love and support.
  • I am also a proud Hoffman Ambassador at Mercy College and have committed to volunteering 250 hours to my local community within this school year. My recent/current volunteering opportunities have been coaching the Monac 1st &
column2: 2nd grade cross country team and helping out in the 5th-8th classrooms at Queen of Apostles School two days each week. While being a Hoffman Ambassador allows me to engage my local community, the Guatemala trip will allow me to engage not only a different culture but my broader world community!

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

    I know some people just can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
• Please help me spread the word to others that may be in the position to contribute and make some noise about my trip by using the indiegogo share tool.

Thank you,

Elizabeth

Hey guys!

Rosemarie is a super sweet lady. She tries her hardest to make ends meet, but her ex husband is copping out of child support this winter. She's worried about not being able to give her kids a Christmas and I say that we can do something about that. If you can contribute even one dollar, it will be most, most appreciated. Lets try and make Christmas a little easier for someone who really deserves it.

Here is what it is all about:

Hi there! My name is Maggie Roberts,  also sometimes known as the Undressed Lady of Undressing the Historical Lady and the blogger behind a couple of popular, amusing, and educational blogs
column2:
Serendipitous Stitchery and The Diary of Miss Emily Waterman. 

I am an avid living historian but also an educator
column3:
teaching the public about fashion history in the 18th and early 19th centuries. It is a fun and informative lecture, that is loved by many and has afforded me some amazing opportunities.

And the best is yet to come. I have been given an internship opportunity by what many people consider to be the height of 18th century living history and knowledge - Colonial Williamsburg, to better learn about the trade, historical sewing, and the fashions of the time. Even though I've never been able to afford to go to college, I took a chance and applied for the internship anyway. I was amazed they even considered me and I am so thankful that Colonial Williamsburg is giving a living historian and hobbiest such a chance.

I love the career I have chosen for my self passionately, and I cannot imagine myself doing anything else, and this opportunity will take me so far in improving my education of the public, and my representation in the era of the Revolutionary War, which is very important to me. I hope that you also feel it is important, and are willing to help me out on this amazing adventure.


The Nitty Gritty parts:

column1: Unfortunately, this years Undressing lectures alone wont be able to support my endeavor, and equally as unfortunate I am without a wealthy benefactor and will not be inheriting a long lost-realitve's fortune any time soon like so many of our favorite literary heros, and on top of that the internship itself is unpaid. Therefore, the goal for this campaign is to raise
$4,000.00. Those funds will be split between a number of things:
<ul>
• Housing costs, like rent and utilities for two
months
• Food and other necessities for two months
• Airplane tickets to and from Virginia from
Tennessee
• Emergency Funds
And the good news is whenever you donate, YOU WIN! There are
some really amazing perks that I am offering at almost all price points. For
the lower donation amounts, I am offering for $1 donations a hug or high
five depending on what you choose and that perk is good until I keel over dead. If
you see me and you donated, tell me and I will happily provide! All the way up to limited edition handmade
clothing pieces such as shifts, chemisettes, and caps personalized for
the donator. There are even perks for the group donators. Just head to the perks section and see if anything catches
your fancy. Just want to donate but  don't want a perk? Thats ok too, and you will still receive a hand written note for your time and contribution.
So,
Why?
You’re probably asking yourself, why is this important to
me and to anyone else? Easy! History is ALWAYS important and there is so much more to history than
dates, names, and battles. There is the culture and the lifestyle these men and
women in our past experienced daily that we often don’t think or learn about in school,
or out of it.  That is
where I come in, and that is where this internship can help! There is so much
to be learned from this opportunity that I can then pass on to all of you! I
will be able to gain a much better understanding of the fashions of the past
and the trade of a Milliner-Mantua Maker that can’t be learned in books alone
but through living it daily and DOING it. It is what some of us like to refer
to as “experimental archaeology”, and is just as important and valuable to
education as a textbook can be.
As an educator, the importance of relaying correct and
well-researched history and knowledge is priceless
have to put a price on it so we can gain that appropriate knowledge. I hope
that you think teaching history in a fun, informative, and different way is as
important as I do, and you will donate to this project to keep a fascinating part of history alive and even sparking a new love and interest in generations to
it worth it?
Of course, this can’t always be so easy, but as my husband
loves to say “you have thrown your ball over the fence, now go and get it!” and
I definitely mean to. Is there a chance that people will not find this cause worthy
of their time and money? Absolutely, but that is not going to stop me from
trying – this is as important to others in the end as it is to me.  There will be ups and downs along the way, I
am certain, and there is always the chance I won’t meet my goal – but that
doesn’t mean I will give up my opportunity at this internship. It wont be the first time I face a mountain of challenges and work, and it wont be the last, either.
If it seems like I won’t reach my final goal, don’t let that
stop you from donating. As I said earlier, your kind contributions will not be
for nothing, and every penny will go towards being able to accomplish my dream
of completing this internship.
Help isn't just about sending money!
Can’t donate
but still want to help? Worry not! There are SO many ways in which you can
provide assistance
column2: the main thing you can do to help is get the word out

column1: there as much as possible. Spread it around on Facebook, Instagram, Blogs, and Twitter. Exposure is the most important part of this project, and Indiegogo has
amazing tools to help you share!
But when all
else fails, a hug is a massive help whenever it is needed or can be given.
Thank you
everyone for helping, and for supporting not only myself, but the living
history community!

to as “experimental archaeology”, and is just as important and valuable to
education as a textbook can be.
As an educator, the importance of relaying correct and
well-researched history and knowledge is priceless
have to put a price on it so we can gain that appropriate knowledge. I hope
that you think teaching history in a fun, informative, and different way is as
important as I do, and you will donate to this project to keep a fascinating part of history alive and even sparking a new love and interest in generations to
come.Is
it worth it?
Of course, this can’t always be so easy, but as my husband
loves to say “you have thrown your ball over the fence, now go and get it!” and
I definitely mean to. Is there a chance that people will not find this cause worthy
of their time and money? Absolutely, but that is not going to stop me from
trying – this is as important to others in the end as it is to me.  There will be ups and downs along the way, I
am certain, and there is always the chance I won’t meet my goal – but that
doesn’t mean I will give up my opportunity at this internship. It wont be the first time I face a mountain of challenges and work, and it wont be the last, either.
If it seems like I won’t reach my final goal, don’t let that
stop you from donating. As I said earlier, your kind contributions will not be
for nothing, and every penny will go towards being able to accomplish my dream
of completing this internship.
Help isn't just about sending money!
Can’t donate
but still want to help? Worry not! There are SO many ways in which you can
provide assistance
column2: the main thing you can do to help is get the word out

column1: there as much as possible. Spread it around on Facebook, Instagram, Blogs, and Twitter. Exposure is the most important part of this project, and Indiegogo has
amazing tools to help you share!
But when all
else fails, a hug is a massive help whenever it is needed or can be given.
Thank you
everyone for helping, and for supporting not only myself, but the living
history community!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Old Hickory, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/educating-the-undressed-lady/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Summary
Each year the Rotary Youth Exchange provides 8,000 high school
students from 80 countries a life-changing opportunity to live
in another country for about a month in the summer in the short term
program or for a school year in the long term program. <strong>While RYE is one of the least
costly programs of this type, the cost is still beyond the ability of worthy
students.
Our Goal
Rotary District 6150 in central and northeast Arkansas has begun a 30 day campaign to raise
funds for its Scholarship Fund to enable more worthy Arkansas students in our district to have this life-changing opportunity.  No student
from our district will be given a 100% scholarship. <strong>We are aiming to raise a total of
$5,000, half through this campaign and half through our annual silent
auction at the Rotary District 6150 Conference, April 17-18, 2015.
The Impact
The students who have experienced another culture tell it best:
Finn from Wynne who went on a short term exchange to Sweden
says: I had a wonderful time on my trip to Sweden…. <strong>It was an
experience I will never forget. I got to visit buildings and other
historical locations that have been around long before America was even an idea, which I
found to be very cool. I got to learn about daily life in a different country
and celebrate a few holidays as well. In Sweden,
we walked and biked all over Stockholm,
and visited many museums.
Lauren from Cabot on a long term exchange in Germany
says:  So far Germany
has been amazing. I landed at the Hannover
Airport on the 14th and drove for
about an hour to my city of Minden.
It's the cutest city with many old, old buildings.  I started school last
week and there are 7 Rotary exchange students there. So far I'm the only
North American"" but there are 3 South Americans! I went to the first
inbound meeting last weekend.  We got familiar with the district rules,
got to meet the other students, and even got to perform and introduction for
our country!  This weekend I will be going to Essen for the first Rotex Weekend.<strong> I
will have to take the train which I've never done before! I have to ride
a bike to and from school and I've already fallen off, which was
a traumatizing experience.
<h3>Risks &amp
Let’s help make these experiences available to all qualified students
regardless of their financial ability. They especially can gain so much
from the experience. We can’t do it without your help.
Other Ways You Can Help
We very much value other contributions to the District Youth Exchange
Program. It takes many people working together to provide such cultural
experiences to our high school students.
<ul>
<li>Rotary Clubs telling local
students about the program and encouraging them to apply regardless of
their financial ability.
<li>Rotarians and non-Rotarians
volunteering to be host families for long term exchange students.
<li>Rotary Clubs individually or
in association of two together hosting a long term foreign exchange
student
<li>You can ask questions about
the program by filling in the “contact us” form at rotary6150.org/go/ye.

Short Summary

Labor of Love UAE, Libraries for Labor Camps and the Society for Emirates Voluntary Activities have teamed up with the Welfare Department of ETA Ascon to help laborers at ETA Ascon's Musaffah camp.  We have started English language classes and now we want to build a library for these laborers.  We are taking donations of reading materials (see more below), but we would also like to include quality materials for learning English.

The first fundraising goal is to buy these materials (email us at laborofloveuae@hotmail.com and we would be happy to send you the list of what we will be buying).  If we manage to raise this - which we hope we do! - we will start another campaign to buy CD players and headphones for the audio materials, and also to build a similar library in another camp that is off the Al Ain highway.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

To reach our first goal we need AED 4,241 (the site sets goals in US Dollars and we have adjusted to accomodate for fees charged by the site, which are minimal, and the actual exchange rate offered by banks).
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
<div>
Please also consider donating books in Urdu, Hindi, Tamil and Bengali.  We also need CD players and headphones - used or new.

column1: We still need $6,911 - let's keep the momentum going so please help spread the word!
<h3><span style=""font-size: 1.17em

Satisfy your obligation to write a Sefer Torah by participating in the completion of this Torah and owning a piece of it for yourself or your family. The Lubavitcher Rebbe spoke many times of the great benefits of ""buying a letter"" in the Torah and suggested that everyone should get one for themselves and each member of their family.

This torah is being written to honor the life of Kazi Benjamin (Kasriel ben Yehuda) who was taken from us too soon, at the young age of 25. Kazi touched the lives of everyone he met and left behind a legacy of kindness and compassion. The Torah is everlasting and reading from it on Shabbat, holidays and other occasions is a most fitting tribute and zchus to him. Help us complete this Sefer Torah in time for his 2nd yohrtzeit (anniversary of passing) coming up on August 25.
<div>
We're almost there
We've raised over half the money and with your help we can get the last little bit:
<ul>
• The cost of the sefer torah is $30,000.
• So far, we've raised almost $20,000 and are setting the goal to completion at $10,000.
• Additional funds raised will go to the purchase of a mantel (Torah cover), a crown (keser) and the ""siyum sefer torah"" event to be held in Crown Heights, Brooklyn on 8/25.
• There are dedication opportunities at every price point and each dollar counts, so please contribute whatever you can and help make this worthwhile cause become a reality!
• Your donations are tax-deductible with all fundraising being managed by Itchke's Shtiebel a registered NYS religious corporation.
<div>
What else?

The Torah will be housed at Itchke's Shtiebel synagogue, where Kazi was a founding member, and will become the primary Torah scroll to be used regularly throughout the year. ""The Shtiebel"" has been providing religious and social services to the young adults in the greater Crown Heights, Brooklyn community for over 5 years and is lead by the esteemed Rabbi Chaim Fogelman.  Any additional funds raised over the amount needed for the Torah will go to support The Shtiebel's ongoing Torah classes and community programs in Kazi's memory.
<div>
Help get the word out
Your donation is much appreciated but so is your involvement! Help get the word out by sharing to Facebook &
column2: Twitter, using the sharing tools above

Help me become a Waldorf Teacher!

• Hi!  I'm Stasha.  I'm a storyteller and mama and have been an alternative educator for many years.  I want to make a greater impact in the field of educational renewal and within the lives of children today.  I need Waldorf teacher training in order to grow as an educator and leader of educational reform.

• I have wanted to be a Waldorf teacher for over 15 years.  I appreciate aspects of every educational system --from the public to the alternative--however, I have discovered that Waldorf education nurtures the life of the soul within the child, the teacher and the education system. And I think that soul in human beings and soul is education matters.  A lot.
<ul>

• Waldorf Teacher training is very affordable. I chose the training in Eugene, Oregon because it is the least expensive training center out of only a handful of training centers around the world.  It is a 2 year, part-time training at $4800/year or $480/month for 20 months.  However, I don't have the financial abundance necessary to cover this expense in addition to my monthly expenses of housing, bills, and my daughter's schooling. Scholarships and financial aid are not available during the first year.

• I'm reaching out to you for help!  Crowd-source funding has assisted MANY individuals and groups achieve their dreams.  Please consider helping me to achieve my dream by donating.  For as little as the cost of your morning latte, you are making an enormous contribution!

• I've worked with children all my life - as a nanny in the US and abroad, then as a facilitator/teacher within afterschool and summer camps.  I've also been an assistant or co-teacher in Montessori, Waldorf, Reggio Emilia and nature-based learning environments.  In addition, I have created Waldorf inspired homeschool programs.  I have wondered --what makes a human being free?  I have also wondered what system of education truly creates well-balanced, intelligent, free-thinking, soulful, practical and embodied leaders in our world today.  I have found the greatest resonance with my soul-searching in Waldorf education.

• Waldorf education is balanced, holistic and inspiring.  I see Waldorf education as a visionary and transformational movement facilitating educational renewal and bringing clear-minded, disciplined, intelligent, curious and creative young people into the world. I am aware of the challenges of being an educator today - whether one enters a traditional or alternative learning environment.  I rise with passion to meet these challenges today and am EXCITED to become an educator within a educational system that asks: what is a human being and what makes a human being and how do we educate so that the human being is free.

• I will become a certified Waldorf teacher within 2 years and will be able to teach within a Waldorf school anywhere in the world.  I will even be able to create my own school with a group of inspired families.  Anywhere!  My dream is to lead a group of first through eighth graders through Waldorf inspired curriculum in a foreign country.

• You will be supporting my inner development as a human being and teacher - this is an instrumental part of becoming a Waldorf teacher - spiritual blossoming, deepening awareness and embodied leadership as a teacher.
• Your help will contribute directly to the movement of education renewal in the world.
<h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-weight: normal
Here's the Breakdown:
• I need $4800 to attend the training.  That is $480 a month for 10 months.  If 100 people donate $5, that is $500 towards my foundation year training.
• Depending on your level of financial contribution, I have exciting transformative language arts offerings. Please keep reading!
<h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-weight: normal

column13: >Waldorf education is a humanistic approach to pedagogy based on the educational philosophy of the Austrian philosopher Rudolf Steiner, the founder of anthroposophy. (That's a mouthful!) The first Waldorf school was founded in 1919 in Stuttgart, Germany.
>At present there are over 1,000 independent Waldorf schools,
column18: > and 646 centers for
column19: >located in 80 nations. There are also Waldorf-based state schools, charter schools, academies
column20: > and homeschooling

column10: >The educational philosophy's overarching goal is to develop free, morally responsible and integrated individuals equipped with a high degree of social competence. Waldorf teachers are interested in students as individuals. They are interested in the questions:

column1: <li style=""margin-top: 0px
column10: >How do we establish within each child his or her own high level of academic excellence?

column1: <li style=""margin-top: 0px
column10: >How do we call forth enthusiasm for learning and work, a healthy self-awareness, interest and concern for fellow human beings, and a respect for the world?

column1: <li style=""margin-top: 0px
column10: >How can we help pupils find meaning in their lives?

column9: >Teachers in Waldorf schools are dedicated to generating an inner enthusiasm for learning within every child. Even seemingly dry and academic subjects are presented dynamically and expressively, through stories and the humanistic ways of teaching. This eliminates the need for competitive testing, academic placement, and behavioristic rewards to motivate learning. It allows motivation to arise from within and helps engender the capacity for joyful lifelong learning.
column13:
>Other Ways You Can Help
  • If you can't contribute a donation at this time, please consider helping me by spreading the word.

column1:
Thank you!  Thank you!  Thank you!  I appreciate your consideration and your support so deeply.

I've worked with children all my life - as a nanny in the US and abroad, then as a facilitator/teacher within afterschool and summer camps.  I've also been an assistant or co-teacher in Montessori, Waldorf, Reggio Emilia and nature-based learning environments.  In addition, I have created Waldorf inspired homeschool programs.  I have wondered --what makes a human being free?  I have also wondered what system of education truly creates well-balanced, intelligent, free-thinking, soulful, practical and embodied leaders in our world today.  I have found the greatest resonance with my soul-searching in Waldorf education.

I will become a certified Waldorf teacher within 2 years and will be able to teach within a Waldorf school anywhere in the world.  I will even be able to create my own school with a group of inspired families.  Anywhere!  My dream is to lead a group of first through eighth graders through Waldorf inspired curriculum in a foreign country.

What I Need & What You Get

Depending on your level of financial contribution, I have exciting transformative language arts offerings. Please keep reading!
What is Waldorf Education Anyway?

Waldorf education is a humanistic approach to pedagogy based on the educational philosophy of the Austrian philosopher Rudolf Steiner, the founder of anthroposophy. (That's a mouthful!) The first Waldorf school was founded in 1919 in Stuttgart, Germany.

At present there are over 1,000 independent Waldorf schools, 2,000 kindergartens and 646 centers for located in 80 nations. There are also Waldorf-based state schools, charter schools, academies and homeschooling environments.

The educational philosophy's overarching goal is to develop free, morally responsible and integrated individuals equipped with a high degree of social competence. Waldorf teachers are interested in students as individuals. They are interested in the questions:
How do we establish within each child his or her own high level of academic excellence?
How do we call forth enthusiasm for learning and work, a healthy self-awareness, interest and concern for fellow human beings, and a respect for the world?
How can we help pupils find meaning in their lives?

Teachers in Waldorf schools are dedicated to generating an inner enthusiasm for learning within every child. Even seemingly dry and academic subjects are presented dynamically and expressively, through stories and the humanistic ways of teaching. This eliminates the need for competitive testing, academic placement, and behavioristic rewards to motivate learning. It allows motivation to arise from within and helps engender the capacity for joyful lifelong learning.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute a donation at this time, please consider helping me by spreading the word.
Thank you!  Thank you!  Thank you!  I appreciate your consideration and your support so deeply.",1.0,0,"3 Campaigns

While at Archbishop Porter Girls' Secondary School (APGSS) in Takoradi, Ghana we noticed there were close to 20 computers in the school's ICT room. There are 1600 girls enrolled at the school, imagine having to wait for weeks to use a computer and then to only have a short time to use it. Secondly and importantly, the school had the best wifi connection in all of Ghana! APGSS is under the direction and leadership of Headmistress Louisa C. Aggrey.

On the issue of books, the school's librarian begged us for more books each time she walked near us. The girls, most who are avid readers, have read the same titles over and over again. There is no funding in the Ghanaian education structure for library books. WE can assist these young people in both computers and library books, in acquiring comunity power through advances in their education.

The RESPECT Alliance, founded by Connie Grier, is hosting the fundraising so that your contributions can be made tax-deductible. Even if you cannot attend the event, you can contribute, your donation will be only for the use of books and computers. All monies collected in the final week of this campaign will be used for shipping costs and any duty fees that we will incur. I am returning to Ghana to meet the shipment in August, prior to the close of the school year.
Please help us in this initial fundraising effort!

Who Are We?

We are a team of 26 undergraduate students from Western University in London, Ontario. With the help of over 800 student volunteers and 6000 first-year students, we organize and host the largest post-secondary Terry Fox Run in Canada and one of the most successful Shinerama campaigns in support of cystic fibrosis research in the country. Our team was founded roughly 20 years ago and our campaigns have been steadily growing in size and success.

We recognize that Western's Orientation Week provides us with an incredible opportunity to change the way we think about role of youth in creating change. We believe in giving back to something beyond ourselves and in uniting thousands of students, along with our communities, we hope to lead and empower others to join the fight against two terrible diseases that directly or indirectly affect everyone. We are shameless idealists
column2: we reject the statistics that say two in three Canadians will battle cancer in their lifetimes and we refuse to accept diagnosis of cystic fibrosis as a death sentence. In the past two years, we have raised nearly $400,000 for cancer and cystic fibrosis research and this year, we are determined to raise even more. Through education, fundraising and community activism, we hope that we will see a cure for cancer and cystic fibrosis in our lifetimes.

column1: <div>

Our team spends 5 months every year gearing up for numerous awareness and fundraising events that occur during Orientation Week at Western University - but, we operate without a budget. Each year, we start from scratch, turning $0 into $220,000 (in 2011) and creating a whole lot of awareness. Our campaigns truly rely on the generosity of those who support us and on the creativity and innovation of our student body. 

Our team is broken down into 14 portfolios, responsible for organizing specific components of our campaign:
<ul>
<li>
Leadership Team (3 chairs responsible for managing the team and coordinating with the foundations)
<ul>
<li>
Terry Fox Run Day Coordinators (2 students who organize the logistics of the run itself, as well as various awareness programming and entertainment that occurs during the event)
<li>
Shine Day Coordinators (2 students who coordinate over 7000 students canvassing London for donations, operating carwashes, busking and creating awareness about cystic fibrosis)
<li>

Shine Fest (2 coordinators who are planning our newest initiative, a sports day in a city park for children - this event incorporates the community in our campaigns, promotes healthy living and preventative measures and teaches children and adults about what it is like to live with CF)
<li>
Awareness Programming (2 coordinators who plan various events designed to teach students about our causes in unique and interactive ways)
<li>
Media (3 talented individuals who create all of our videos, web activity, graphics and social media so we may spread our message as creatively and to as many people as possible)
<li>
Finance (2 students who handle donations and sponsorship and ensure that our campaigns are running in a cost-effective manner)
<li>
Conference Coordinators (2 students who plan a conference weekend for our student volunteers to train them and educate them to help us run our campaigns)
<li>
Sponsorship (1 student who connects with businesses in the community for gifts and donations to help us turn a small amount of resources into big results)
<li>
Merch (1 creative student who designs and handles all of the merchandise and swag we sell during our campaigns)
<li>

Food (2 coordinators who plan and run all of our BBQs and food sales during our campaigns - they are responsible for feeding the whole campus during O-Week as hospitality services don't start running until classes start!)
<li>
Physical Promo (1 student who creates all of our physical materials, including banners, posters and guerilla marketing tactics such as projector bombs and community art projects)
<li>
Golf Tournament (1 student who organizes our Alumni and Student golf tournament)

Since we do not have a budget to plan our campaigns with, our events and activities can only be as big as what we have in our bank account and depends on what kinds of materials and entertainment we can have donated. We try to spend as little as possible and keep a close watch on our finances to make sure we are getting big results out of every single penny. With your generosity and support, we can make our events and promotions bigger than ever, reaching a larger audience and encouraging more people to join our fight. This means we are able to donate even more to the Terry Fox Foundation and Shinerama.

$0.84 of every dollar raised for the Terry Fox Foundation goes to cancer research and for every year that Shinerama fundraises, 10 months is added to the life expectancy of individuals living with cystic fibrosis. We fundraise for these two foundations because we believe that they make our donations go as far as possible, creating real change for people suffering from cancer and cystic fibrosis.
<div>

We know that there are tons of people raising money and awareness for cancer research, however this disease is quickly turning into an epidemic. Our efforts may be a small contribution in the large scale of cancer fundraising, but the more our university raises, the more universities around Canada raise. Further, we believe our student body offers unique and creative ideas for fundraising and we hope to advocate for youth activism in a way that has never been done before. With your donations, we can grow our campaigns and change the way we think about the role of youth in fundraising forever.

Shinerama has made progress for cystic fibrosis patients in leaps and bounds, and our campaigns have long been the one of the biggest in Canada. Since Shinerama was founded, the life expectancy for children diagnosed with CF has risen from 6 years old to 47. In 2011, Shinerama campaigns by post-secondary students raised over $1 million across Canada and the organization is rapidly growing. At Western, we raised over $50,000 last year simply by pulling a 15 tonne fire-truck across campus and since 1968, Western alone has raised $2.98 million. Shinerama campaigns are funding life-saving research that is drastically changing the realities of those living with cystic fibrosis and every day we get closer to making CF stand for ""Cure Found"".

We hope our campaigns will educate students and the community about the realities of cancer and cystic fibrosis and persuade them that civic activism is crucial to curing these two devastating diseases. With your help, we can inspire thousands of people to make a commitment to the fight against cancer and CF and hopefully create levels of community involvement that will someday be capable of funding a cure. We also want to encourage people to look after themselves and their families, never take their health for granted and take preventative measures to ensure that cancer is found and cured early. We are just a small group of students, but we have seen our campaigns grow exponentially in the past decade and we believe that with support, we have the power to create something that will change our communities. Attitude is everything and Unity is Strength.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially to our causes, but advocacy and awareness is just as essential to our success as fundraising is. Please share our video and our message, join Terry Fox Runs (or start one!) in your area, and spread the word about cystic fibrosis.

From the bottom of our hearts, thank you so much for your generosity and for being a part of our search for a cure.

Important News about our Campaign! With only 3 days left to meet our goal, an anonymous donor has generously offered to double match every dollar donated to Esther’s Aid on Indiegogo with a double donation to Hurricane Sandy victims! So please donate today and you'll be helping our Heavenly Bakery students and our neighbors in need in New York and New Jersey as well.
…Who are We?

Esther's Aid for Needy and Abandoned Children is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization dedicated to its primary mission to respond to the need of children orphaned by war and diseases, vulnerable girls, the poor, and the outcast.  In recent years our mission has evolved to include hundreds of poor women ravaged with poverty, homelessness and HIV/AIDS.

Following the 1994 Rwandan genocide, in which nearly one million civilians were killed, and many thousands of children left homeless, founder Clare Effiong came to Rwanda to witness the aftermath first hand. She was stunned by the complete devastation. It is here that our story begins. One day, while providing food to homeless orphans, Clare felt inclined to find out what these children truly wanted, more than anything else.   Most of course asked for food, safety, or medical assistance.  But one small, eight-year-old orphan, Wayesu Justus, aspired instead for something different: an education.
Around this child’s one request, Esther’s Aid was born.
What Do We Do?

Since its founding, Esther’s Aid has built learning institutions that allow many more orphans like Wayesu to thrive.  Our skills training programs provide students with the skills they need to make a better life for themselves. With the jobs they find after graduation, they are permanently lifted out of poverty.  And as for Wayesu – today he is the top-ranked student at his elite high school in Kigali and he hopes to one day study medicine in America.
How Do We Do It?
Esther's Aid provides children, youth, and poor women with tools for a productive life through basic education, skills and job training, and employment.
Since 2000, Esther’s Aid has:
<ul>
• Reached out to over 3,000 orphans and needy street children/youth/widows.
• Rehabilitated and reintegrated hundreds of children, and opened a free primary school.
• Established skills training for youth in catering,baking, and sewing.
<li>Established the <strong><a href=""http://www.esthersaid.org/index.php?option=com_content&amp
column4: Itemid=85"" rel=""nofollow noopener"">Heavenly Bakery facility, and skills empowerment centers to create economic opportunity for youth and poor women in Rwanda:

column1: This is Why We Need Your Help!

The van we use to deliver the baked goods from our Heavenly Bakery recently broke down and students are now forced to walk several miles on foot delivering bread around the neighborhood in Kigali. This is making it very difficult for us to fulfill our orders which have recently included wedding cakes!  We need $2000 to ship a gently used donated van from New Jersey to Kigali to keep our bakery profitable.  All profits from the bakery go directly to fund our programs.  And did I mention our van does double duty? When we're not delivering bread we use it to transport our elementary school children to and from school as well!
How You Can Help and Receive a Hand Crafted Gift from Esther's Aid

Every donation counts– no matter the amount - so in advance , THANK YOU VERY, VERY MUCH for whatever you can give!  But take a look at the incentive gifts at the different donation levels.  Remember that your donations provide a hand up not a hand out!
Why Esther's Aid?

Over 12 years ago, Clare Effiong, left a comfortable career as a UN diplomat to travel to Rwanda to help those in need.  With no more than $150 in her pocket Clare ventured out into a country that was unfamiliar to her, but within days she was making a difference in the lives of the orphaned and abandoned youth. many of whom were living with HIV/AIDS.

The youth and women of Rwanda are rewriting their story, and it starts with education and economic opportunity.  Clare's intense passion and commitment to the people of Rwanda inspired me to get involved. I believe you will be inspired as well. By the way we have no paid administrative staff in New York. Every dollar funds our programs in Rwanda.

Please watch the short video we just made to see how your donations, big and small, can change a life from hopelessness and poverty to ""the life that has hope."" 
- Carmen Paolercio,  Volunteer Development Coordinator

Travelling abroad can enhance student’s course of study, immerse them in another culture, allow them opportunities to improve foreign language skills, and give them the opportunity to meet new people and experience new places. Perhaps more importantly, studying overseas will help produce global citizens by opening the doors to intercultural understanding.

For students in the Philadelphia public school system, a trip overseas could also be a once-in-a-lifetime, transformative experience.  It has the potential to open students' eyes to the world that exists outside of Philadelphia, to inspire them to explore new places and ideas, and to set higher goals for themselves.
For these reasons, I would like to take a group of British Literature students on a ten day tour of England’s historical and literary sites in the spring of 2013.
Who are we?

We are a British Literature class in a traditionally low-performing public school in North Philadelphia. Although the students are brilliant, we struggle to overcome challenges associated with urban public school systems.  Sadly, many students have had to settle for many years of lackluster education (so lackluster, in fact, that most of the class couldn't even point to England on a map during our first week!).

In an effort to expand horizons and gain deeper insight into the texts we study and the world we live in, a group of exemplary students would like to go on this tour arranged by Education First to explore England's historic literary sites in the spring of 2013:
http://www.eftours.com/educational-tours/tour-detail.aspx?code=APE
What We Need

EF charges approximately 3,000 per student for airfare, accommodation, meals, admission to sites, and transportation.  In order for 6 students to travel, we would need to raise approximately $20,000! It's a large price tag, but we can do it with your help!
<div>

column3: />

column1: Help us get from here...                  to here!

While we are confident in our ability to raise the money we need, if we don't reach our goal, the money we do raise in this campaign will not go to waste. There are many exciting opportunities for field trips in our home city of Philadelphia, and money raised would go to fund an alternative trip to an historical literary site here at home.
What You Get
<div>

What do you get for helping us out? First, you get the pure joy that comes from changing a student's life.  You will also get photos, letters, postcards, poems, and videos from the students as we prepare for our trip and as we travel.  If you're ambitious, you could also come visit our classroom and hear from us in person how much we appreciate your contribution!
<div>
Thank You!

Finally, from the bottom of my heart, thank you! You are making a difference in a student's life.  Who knows, maybe you've just inspired a student who will grow up to be the 21st century's greatest writer, or a future Nobel Prize winner, or first female president of the United States!

Help us get from here...                  to here!

While we are confident in our ability to raise the money we need, if we don't reach our goal, the money we do raise in this campaign will not go to waste. There are many exciting opportunities for field trips in our home city of Philadelphia, and money raised would go to fund an alternative trip to an historical literary site here at home.
What You Get

What do you get for helping us out? First, you get the pure joy that comes from changing a student's life.  You will also get photos, letters, postcards, poems, and videos from the students as we prepare for our trip and as we travel.  If you're ambitious, you could also come visit our classroom and hear from us in person how much we appreciate your contribution!
Thank You!

Finally, from the bottom of my heart, thank you! You are making a difference in a student's life.  Who knows, maybe you've just inspired a student who will grow up to be the 21st century's greatest writer, or a future Nobel Prize winner, or first female president of the United States!",2.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Philadelphia, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/transform-a-student-s-life-send-our-class-abroad/pica

0,"

The video you see above is a snippet of one of our educational programs. It's our favorite tea lab Battle of the Bakers from 2012, where two award-winning chefs competed in creating tea-infused desserts. The audience, comprised of tea lovers, tasted the desserts and judged the chefs, while also learned how to use tea in their own dessert making.

Our Tea Lovers Festival has three levels of Educational Programming: Tea Tastings (introductory), Tea Studies (mid-level, includes tastings + lecture) and Tea Labs, which are either interactive or hands-on workshops. We are also one of the only tea festivals in the U.S. that incorporates and promotes arts from various world cultures with strong tea traditions.

During past festivals, we have featured art, music and dance from India, China, Japan, Great Britain and other countries. We've also screened tea documentaries, such as The Meaning of Tea and All In This Tea, plus cultural films like Hannari: Geisha Modern, all with talks by the filmmakers.

To sum it up, our Tea Lovers Festival is an annual event that happens every spring in Los Angeles, but we also produce other educational and cultural programs, such as our popular Tea Lovers Bus Tours in San Francisco, San Diego and Ojai. CLICK HERE to view images from our 2015 Tea Lovers Festival. In addition, you can view past programming content and images on the ARCHIVES section of our website: TeaLoversFestival.com. Also, check out the GALLERY section above.


WHY DO WE NEED FUNDING?

We are currently in our 10th year as a public event – we are one of the longest running tea festival in the United States. And to celebrate this important milestone, we've recently completed a 10th Anniversary Celebration on February 14, 2016 at the Fowler Museum at UCLA, with music and dance from countries with strong tea traditions. We're also currently planning a 10th Anniversary Book Release on May 1, 2016 at USC Pacific Asia Museum (see below).

Even though we've been around for a decade, this type of festival is still new and unique to the tea industry, so we hardly get any financial support from large tea companies – we rely primarily on the support from our audiences of tea lovers. And we have many, many production expenses. However, any funds that we're able to raise through Indiegogo, would be applied towards our 10th Anniversary Book Release event – for any printing costs, as well as for venue/equipment rentals and honorariums to the tea ceremony master/pupils and musicians, who will be performing at the event.

We would love to actually go beyond our fundraising goal listed here, so Indiegogo can allow us to continue to raise funds with this campaign after its deadline and we won't have to create a new one in the near future.

So we hope that you will contribute to this fundraising effort, as ultimately this festival belongs to everyone – it's really a community-based cultural event, which revolves around tea. For the tea lover in all of us! :-)

PERKS/REWARDS
With any perk level, your name will be included in our 10the anniversary retrospective book (see below).

THE 10TH ANNIVERSARY BOOK RELEASE
Sunday, May 1, 2016 >
column4:
Pasadena, California

This book release event will include traditional Japanese Tea Ceremonies, under the conduct of renown tea master Soshitsu Nishimura of the Edo Senke Sado School, live music by Tsugaru shamisen player Mike Penny, as well as a talk by Kulov, our Tea Lovers Festival's founder and creative director, who will give insights into the history of the festival over the past decade. 

Perk Levels: TEA ENTHUSIAST 02, TEA LOVER 02*, TEA DEVOTEE 02* and TEA CONNOISSEUR 02*.

Note: *Tickets for our 10th Anniversary Book Release to those contributing at these perk levels will be available at Will Call at the Pacific Asia Museum's on May 1, 2016. The printed book, however, will be mailed directly to you during the months of May and June, 2016.

THE BOOK
Our Tea Lovers Festival: 10 Years retrospective book is an 8 x 10 inches (20 x 25 cm), 130-150+ pages visual exploration of all of our ten tea festivals, as well as of our tea bus tours in Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego and Ojai. In addition to hundreds of images, it also contains ten years of various texts, press, stories and anecdotes. Plus something NEW – for each of its 15 chapters, we'll be asking some of our esteemed tea chefs and educators, such as Robert Wemischner, Kristy Choo, Steve Schwartz and Zhena Muzyka, to contribute various tea-related recipes on cooking, tea blending and other such topics. The book will be released in 4 different versions:

Digital Version: For iPads and other Mac IOS devices (PDF version for non-Mac devices). Perk Levels: TEA LOVER 01 &
column5:
02.
Soft-Cover Version: Or ""reading"" version, on uncoated paper stock with a gloss soft cover. Perk Levels: TEA DEVOTEE 01* &
column6:
02*.
Hard-Cover Version: Coffee-table quality, on coated paper stock. Perk Levels: TEA CONNOISSEUR 01* &
column7:
02*.
Limited-Edition Version: Linen cloth-bound with slip cover (shown above), individually numbered in edition of only 10 copies. Perk Level: TEA DEITY*.

Note: *The printed-book perk levels also include a digital version of the book. Book design shown above is subject to change.
 

THE POSTCARDS
This packet of ten colorful postcards from various Tea Lovers Festivals and Tea Bus Tours over the past decade, with a signed-and-numbered sheet (shown above), is in a limited-edition of 25. Perk Levels: TEA ENTHUSIAST 01 &
column8:
02.

THE BOOKMARK
The special 2 x 6 inches (5 x 15 cm) bookmark, commemorating 10 Years of our Tea Lovers Festival (shown above), is printed in full color on both sides of a heavy, 16pt, matte paper stock. Perk Level: TEA CURIOUS.

RISK &
column9:
CHALLENGES

After our project is funded, we don't foresee any challenges in producing our 10th Anniversary Book Release, as we have a lot of experience in doing these events – this is our 10th year since the festival has been open to the public.

Our Story

Intercultural Coalition for Family Wellness (ICFamWell), a small, totally volunteer-driven non-profit organization, was formed  to provide pro-bono counseling resources and other forms of mentoring support to under-funded, grassroots projects in South America, serving vulnerable communities.

In the past year, ICFamWell launched a Philadelphia initiative - La Puerta Abierta/The Open Door - which serves as a training and mentoring site for bilingual interns and counseling practitioners. They provide free services to families in the Latino immigrant community facing language, social, economic and political barriers. Interns and volunteer practitioners are trained and mentored through a “service learning model” and provide pro bono services in exchange for the clinical experience and mentoring that they receive. The hands-on training and mentoring that bilingual interns and volunteers receive through La Puerta Abierta prepares them to serve these communities, filling a serious void of services and support.
The Impact

In the first year of La Puerta Abierta, we have received referrals and provided family and youth counseling to over 65 immigrant families across the tri-county region of Philadelphia. These are families who typically live in the shadows of our communities due to barriers of language, finances and documentation, yet still struggle with the same stressors as many families: intense conflict, stress, high risk behaviors in youth, depression, poverty, and overall hopelessness. We offer a place of healing and hope as we work with referred families to develop strategies to heal and prevent deterioration of their relationships in the face of their very real challenges. Our services are free, collaborative, confidential, and accessible, deeply respecting cultural and language differences.
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are now launching two groups in the Philadelphia immigrant community that will serve the older children of families who have been deeply impacted by the political and social challenges of immigration. These are youth whose struggles are complicated, even beyond the challenges that are “typical” of adolescence.  In the spirit of our mission, these groups will also serve as a training ground for immigrant, bilingual young adult co-facilitators who represent the communities that we serve.
  In this expansion, we need funds for educational materials to be produced and distributed in both English and Spanish, expansion of our current space to accommodate a growing number of client families, and training and travel stipends for both facilitators and participants.
  Our fundraising goal is $6000. ICFamWell is a 501-c-3 tax-exempt organization. All contributions are tax-deductible. Please consider being part of the La Puerta Abierta family by contributing.

For your contribution:
$10 or less
column2: receive the satisfaction in knowing that you are contributing to a place of healing and hope!

column1: $25 Receive an inspirational Spanish poem in beautiful calligraphy (suitable for framing).
$50- All of the above, and a collection of handouts (in both English and Spanish) produced by ICFamWell relating to ""relationship wellness"", appropriate for personal and/or professional use!

$100- All of the above, and a piece of handcrafted jewelry from South America.

$200- All of the above, and a choice craft from South America

$500- A special recipe book of favorite Latin American dishes complied by our community partners (and if you are a local donor, an special invitation to a future food-filled fiesta!)
$1000- All of the above items, lovingly collected in a beautifully woven tote bag!
