If you give me a fish you have fed me for a day. If you teach me to fish then you have fed me until the river is contaminated or the shoreline seized for development. But if you teach me to organize then whatever the challenge I can join together with my peers and we will fashion our own solution.  – Ricardo Levins Morales
Hey! We at the Wayside Center for Popular Education need YOU to be a part of building a powerful movement in the South!
You can help grow Wayside with this one opportunity!

Wayside Center for Popular Education is a not-for-profit movement resource center which supports social change by training, rejuvenating and connecting activists and organizers, with an emphasis on directly affected communities. We believe that a better world is possible - one built on justice, dignity and solidarity. We also believe that a broad-based social movement is the only way to get there.

Wayside is a place where diverse peoples can come together to reflect on the problems confronting them, heal from the traumas those problems have inflicted, and collectively craft solutions. At and through Wayside, community members and organizers build a regional network of people equipped with the skills and networks needed to mobilize for long term, radical social change
Projects like Wayside depend on raising money from our base, which means reaching out to individual donors.

Grassroots fundraising is the key to being around for the long haul, and we need to get better at it. The GIFT (Grassroots Institute for Fundraising Training) Making Money for our Movements conference happens every two years, and, as a new organization, we need the help!
<div>
What We Need
Here's how it breaks down
<ul>
• $400 Plane Ticket
• $250 Registration Fee
• $50 Transportation (We're 2-3 hours away from the airport!)
This means that if just 40 people give $20, we're there!
<div>

Remember this: By sending us to this conference, you are helping make Wayside a stronger, more capable, more sustaining force for justice. The more money we're able to raise as an organization, the more resources we can put into hiring organizers, paying for trainings, and supporting struggles for a better world.
Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out and make some noise about our fundraiser!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

*note* This specific campaign's donations are not tax deductable! For tax deductable donations, please donate at www.waysidecenter.org/donate and put ""Wayside Fundraising Conference"" in the memo. Thanks!

<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >A Guide To Starting A Worker Cooperative (Explained By Those Who Have Done It)

column1: A nuts 'n' bolts how-to DVD on starting a worker cooperative has been needed and talked about in the workers cooperative community for years.  I have already received inquiries from cities as diverse as Richmond, CA, San Diego, Chicago and New York.  Mark Day, my fellow filmmaker-activist, has generously promised language translation services so that I can include Spanish language option on the DVD. I am also grateful for invaluable support &
column2: consulting advice from the Network of Bay Area Worker Cooperatives, US Federation of Worker Cooperatives, California Center for Cooperative Development as well as individual coop members.  But I need YOU to help me to help others.   America needs jobs now!

column1: This DVD will include creating business plans, types of cooperative structures, creating by-laws, the type of legal and financial terminology that people can expect to encounter, how to prepare to meet with financiers, various funding options, day to day business issues, organizing a structure to deal with conflicts, as well as profiles of diverse cooperatives.  The information will be presented in an upbeat way by cooperative members themselves, as well as attorneys and financial institution experts savvy about cooperatives.

As  the filmmaker (and cooperative member) behind ""This Way Out.""  I am lucky and grateful to be living in a housing cooperative in the San Francisco Bay Area, which is not only home to a fabulous and diverse array of worker and housing cooperatives, but also very rich with cooperative history.  During the Great Depression, grassroots associations such as the UXA (""Unemployed Exchange Association"") and Berkeley Self Sufficiency Association pulled people together and not only employed themselves, but did so with medical coverage and benefits!   With an alarming number of people unemployed, underemployed, or employed in jobs with which they feel dissatisfied, workers cooperatives are a concept that is both time-proven and timely -- and yet many still do not know much about them, let alone how to start one successfully.
<div style="""">
Now is the time.  The UN has declared 2012 ""The Year of Cooperatives.""

The biggest expense is for a camera upgrade ($3000.) The goal is to press 1000 DVD's ($1400) with the rest going to cover production costs.  Target completion is for summer of 2011, but I really need to hit the goal amount.  Getting the camera is the most immediate hold-up.

I will be posting updates on the project as well as some video as I go.  I do need everyone's help in spreading the word.  Do you network with others in your profession? Old schoolmates?  Former cell mates?  Need excuses to pester your ex's?  Please help spread the word about ""THIS WAY OUT.""  And, thank you!

","This Way Out:
A Guide To Starting A Worker Cooperative (Explained By Those Who Have Done It)
The Impact of this DVD tool

A nuts 'n' bolts how-to DVD on starting a worker cooperative has been needed and talked about in the workers cooperative community for years.  I have already received inquiries from cities as diverse as Richmond, CA, San Diego, Chicago and New York.  Mark Day, my fellow filmmaker-activist, has generously promised language translation services so that I can include Spanish language option on the DVD. I am also grateful for invaluable support & consulting advice from the Network of Bay Area Worker Cooperatives, US Federation of Worker Cooperatives, California Center for Cooperative Development as well as individual coop members.  But I need YOU to help me to help others.   America needs jobs now!

This DVD will include creating business plans, types of cooperative structures, creating by-laws, the type of legal and financial terminology that people can expect to encounter, how to prepare to meet with financiers, various funding options, day to day business issues, organizing a structure to deal with conflicts, as well as profiles of diverse cooperatives.  The information will be presented in an upbeat way by cooperative members themselves, as well as attorneys and financial institution experts savvy about cooperatives.

As  the filmmaker (and cooperative member) behind ""This Way Out.""  I am lucky and grateful to be living in a housing cooperative in the San Francisco Bay Area, which is not only home to a fabulous and diverse array of worker and housing cooperatives, but also very rich with cooperative history.  During the Great Depression, grassroots associations such as the UXA (""Unemployed Exchange Association"") and Berkeley Self Sufficiency Association pulled people together and not only employed themselves, but did so with medical coverage and benefits!   With an alarming number of people unemployed, underemployed, or employed in jobs with which they feel dissatisfied, workers cooperatives are a concept that is both time-proven and timely -- and yet many still do not know much about them, let alone how to start one successfully.
Now is the time.  The UN has declared 2012 ""The Year of Cooperatives.""
What The Money Is Needed For

The biggest expense is for a camera upgrade ($3000.) The goal is to press 1000 DVD's ($1400) with the rest going to cover production costs.  Target completion is for summer of 2011, but I really need to hit the goal amount.  Getting the camera is the most immediate hold-up.
Please Help Spread The Word!

I will be posting updates on the project as well as some video as I go.  I do need everyone's help in spreading the word.  Do you network with others in your profession? Old schoolmates?  Former cell mates?  Need excuses to pester your ex's?  Please help spread the word about ""THIS WAY OUT.""  And, thank you!",0.0,0,"3 Campaigns

Summary
• The Communicator is a student-run magazine and online publication (chscommunicator.com) at Community High in Ann Arbor, Michigan.  We write stories that matter.
• Community High is one of the oldest, public alternative high schools in the country.  It provides cutting-edge education in a public setting.
• The Communicator won over 57 state and national awards this year.
• The Communicator Online was a 2015 Pacemaker Finalist.  It is the only school in Michigan to earn this award.

• The Communicator provides students with an authentic audience to publish their work.  Journalism encourages students to engage in their community by interviewing citizens, covering events and forming supported opinions on issues.
• By supporting our organization, you are helping our students to continue writing about topics they are passionate about and publish their work in print and online.
What We Need &
<li>We need at least $5000 to fund the printing of our magazine, resources for our website and equipment for reporting.<span style=""background-color: initial

The Impact

By donating to The Communicator you are helping students to practice valuable writing, editing and design skills, encouraging them to follow their passions, and validating the hard work that they put into each and every article. Please help us reach our goal so that we can continue to share our work with our school and community.

Other Ways You Can Help
• Even if you can't donate you can spread the word about our publication to help us reach our goal!
• You can purchase a subscription to our magazine to enjoy the exciting and informative articles we have to offer.
• You can check out our website to learn more about who we are and what we write about at: chscommunicator.com
","Summary
The Communicator is a student-run magazine and online publication (chscommunicator.com) at Community High in Ann Arbor, Michigan.  We write stories that matter.
Community High is one of the oldest, public alternative high schools in the country.  It provides cutting-edge education in a public setting.
The Communicator won over 57 state and national awards this year.
The Communicator Online was a 2015 Pacemaker Finalist.  It is the only school in Michigan to earn this award.

The Communicator provides students with an authentic audience to publish their work.  Journalism encourages students to engage in their community by interviewing citizens, covering events and forming supported opinions on issues.
By supporting our organization, you are helping our students to continue writing about topics they are passionate about and publish their work in print and online.
What We Need & What You Get
We need at least $5000 to fund the printing of our magazine, resources for our website and equipment for reporting.

The ImpactBy donating to The Communicator you are helping students to practice valuable writing, editing and design skills, encouraging them to follow their passions, and validating the hard work that they put into each and every article. Please help us reach our goal so that we can continue to share our work with our school and community.Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't donate you can spread the word about our publication to help us reach our goal!
You can purchase a subscription to our magazine to enjoy the exciting and informative articles we have to offer.
You can check out our website to learn more about who we are and what we write about at: chscommunicator.com",0.0,0,"4 Campaigns

Summary

Lara is a passionate development team creating an educational app for children who cannot access schools. Our mission is to create a free and open source app and involve people everywhere on Earth in extending the app, and adapting it to different languages and cultures. Our goal is to fight illiteracy globally and give children the opportunities that they deserve. At the moment we are in the beginning of our journey and  are looking for funding to test the first version of the app with children in Tanzania.


The Problem

Today 50 million children worldwide lack access to basic education. On top of that, 250 million children cannot read or write. The main bottleneck is the lack of educated teachers. UNESCO estimates that 1.6 million teachers are lacking in the world today. In addition, many children live in inaccessible places, as nomads, or in war zones, without the possibility to physically access schools. While the world is going digital, and 9 out of 10 Africans have access to a mobile phone, education is lagging behind. There is a huge opportunity to provide education to everyone through mobile devices. We believe that through free, open source, scalable solutions, we can give children access to personalized educational content independent of teachers and classrooms, geographical location, language, and social and financial background.


Our Solution

We are building an educational app targeting, in a first phase, children in rural East Africa. Focus is on basic reading, writing and math, and the app runs on Android tablets and phones. Our starting point was the Global Learning XPRIZE competition, but we are aiming way further than that. We are building an open source solution that will be extended to multiple cultures and languages in all parts of the world where we see children not getting the education they need and have the right to according to the Convention of the rights of the child.


Technology to build on

To reach every child we need the app to be adapted to different languages and cultures. We also want it to be extended and improved by engaged researchers, developers, designers, teachers and passionate people around the globe. We’ve carefully designed the structure of the app to make this process as easy as possible, including separating language and culture specific parts from the basic functionality.


Make it relevant

From the very beginning our target group has been in focus. We know they often can’t access internet, so the app has to work under those premises. We know children with bad eyesight often don’t get glasses, so we made the design simple and clear. We know there is a lack of awareness about sanitation, hygiene and security, so we’ve included these topics in a child friendly way in our digital stories. These are only a few examples on how we are creating digital education that is relevant and actually work for these children!


Social interaction and knowledge sharing

We want to take the learning experience outside of the tablet, and encourage the children to learn together. With a tablet or phone we have a brilliant opportunity to spur interaction by integrating features such as camera, speakers and voice recording, as well as communication between devices, in the learning tasks and challenges. We also stimulate discussion by making content relevant, and by using a very simple tool to light sparks in little minds: ask open-ended questions.


The treehouse is the home space in the app. From here the user can reach all the games and exercises training different aspects of reading writing and math. The treehouse will change with the child’s progress. The three companions are helpers and friends with their own personalities, and show up in different parts of the app.

The Team

L:ara is a non-profit organization registered in Sweden, but with an international composition and network. With our 9 all amazing team members we cover 8 countries on 4 continents.  Designers, developers, researchers, interaction designers, children’s book writers, social entrepreneurs and visionaries, we all work fully non-profit with this project.

Use of Funds

To really make the learning relevant and effective we need to fully understand our users’ needs and how we can maximize their learning. The funds collected through this crowdfunding campaign will be used solely for one purpose: to improve the app through testing with our target group. We’ve been invited to the orphanage Moyo kwa moyo in the village of Matanana in southern Tanzania, to test the app with the children there. This is something we are extremely excited about! We are dedicated to doing the best we can to help these children, and we value if you also feel the urge to help and bring knowledge to those who need it.  



The Future

You are probably asking yourself right now “How are these children gonna get a tablet?”. That’s a perfectly valid question, and we have two main approaches to how to get the app out there.

To reach the children with the absolute highest needs we will partner with organizations working close to these children, like orphanages, community centers or other non-profits. We will provide them with hardware and software to create learning centers, where the children in the villages can come to learn. We are building a network of partners and collaborators around the globe as we speak, where the orphanage Moyo kwa moyo in Tanzania is one of the first nodes in a network that you can be part of growing.

By making the app available directly for download to low-end smartphones, and promote it to our target group, we can reach a lot of children who are not getting proper education today. The use of phones in developing countries has skyrocketed in the last few years. It’s not only a mean to communicate, but also to handle your finances, access weather information for your farming etc. The share of these phones being smartphones is still relatively low, but it’s growing rapidly as prices drop.

The first versions of the app are in Swahili and English, and we already have plans to extend to more cultures and languages. L:ara is an open source project, and together with the engaged community around us and its contributions we all will be able to give education to every child. This campaign is one small step in building that community, and you now have a great opportunity to become a part it!

Call to action

Those €4 we all so often spend on a coffee can really make a difference for a child’s future. Education is the most important factor to lift societies out of poverty. Project L:ara is still in the beginning of a journey, but we know we can make a difference that will create ripples on the water. Now we need your help.
• Back us! We will make your contribution count.
• Make some noise! Share our story and help us reach even further.
• Head over to our website to see how you can be part of the movement.
• Want Lara progress updates? Follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter

We have already received much interest from private individuals and organisations, and in particular, have successfully received funding from KTH Opportunities Fund. An article about L:ara was recently published in the magazine of KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm.

The Talin Women's Resource Center Development Foundation (TWRC) was created by the enthusiasm and guidance of Sir Timothy Straight, the honorary consul of Norway and Finland in Armenia and the founder of Homeland Handicrafts, along with the help of local Armenian woman Gayane Khachatryan and Brian Bokhart, a United States Peace Corps volunteer.  Straight's organization Homeland Handicrafts develops positive handicrafts projects for women around Armenia to create jobs and affect change.  TWRC's work is two fold- both working to create jobs and help mainstream disabled children.
TWRC CREATES JOBS for women through the sale of exquisitely hand-crocheted dolls who wear the costumes of traditional Armenian regions- Moush, Zeytoun, Sebastia and others.

From the profit generated, TWRC will MAINSTREAM DISABLED CHILDREN in the Talin region by creating a disabled children's resource center to identify disabled children, their needs, provide information for parents, training to medical staff, physiotherapy and create a new community for families of special needs children.
Tim, Gayane and Brian care about Armenia and share the desire to provide Armenian children a healthy and positive lifestyle.  They want to create jobs for women in Armenia.
And you can help.
Why this project?
Jobs for women are hard to come by in Talin just as they are elsewhere in Armenia.
There is a worrying lack of information available to the women on health issues, especially those concerning issues related to dietary needs, rights and other areas affecting women and children.

Unfortunately, doctors are not exempt to problems caused by the lack of information available in Armenia.  In one case, a local doctor told the parents of a child with a lazy eye he would be blind by the time he was 20.  The family was terrified for what the future would bring.
Something needs to be done.
What we need...
TWRC has received seed money to get a project identifying and mainstreaming disabled children in the Talin region on its feet.  Yet, there are needs:
a table and chairs $400
a color printer $250
an overhead projector $500
a car to get the kids to physiotherapy sessions $4,500
seed money to start a revolving fund for materials to make the dolls $1000
With $6,650 all of these expenses can be covered while also securing a solid basis for the project in the future.

If additional funding is received, TWRC will hire a regular project driver to include more children in the program, and compensate a specialist on child development that will visit Talin regularly. Furthermore, other issues relevant to the current living condition of women in Talin will be addressed. There is no lack of needs that can be addressed to elevate the women in the Talin region further up the socio-economic ladder.
What helping TWRC means for you...
Today there are six women working away at making dolls for you to receive as a reward for contribution.  Today, TWRCF makes 10 different women dolls:
Moush
Trabizon
Khotojour
Vaspourakan
Karin(Erzroum)
Zeytoun
Sebastia
Sasoun
Van
Artsakh
Each of the dolls can be viewed on the Talin dolls website
Shipment of the perks you claim will take place from the local Talin post office, right to your door.  The cost of this is included in the amount you contribute for the perk.

Our hope is that TWRC will go far beyond the goal of $6,650 and will mirror the succes of the recently launched Berd Bear project.  With the additional funding received, TWRC will be able to expand our work-- employing more women and helping new villages identify and mainstream disabled chidren.
TWRC expects to mail all doll orders from Armenia before December 1st.  This means you will have the dolls by Christmas (or at least the Armenian Christmas!)

Should TWRC falls short of their goal of $6.650(please, no!), we will still continue our project. However, the reality of decreased resources means fewer women will be employed and fewer children helped.
If you can't contribute financially...
Spread the word!  Link it on Facebook, Twitter, everywhere possible.  Tell your church, tell your local Armenian newspaper--  TWRC needs your help to get the word out.

Just as the project is not only about raising money, but also raising awareness, so is this Indiegogo campaign.  TWRC is an ambitious, positive young organization, and deserves to be in the spotlight.  Helping to be a link in information sharing will allow more people in Armenia, diasporans abroad, and other concerned citizens of the world to know what needs exist in Talin and how they can be addressed in an effective, quality and low cost way.

Our Story

The Yoknapatawpha Arts Council is the official arts agency for Oxford and Lafayette County, with one full-time staff member, a twelve member Board of Directors, and volunteers working to transform the creative works of artists, performers, musicians, and writers into programs that create jobs, attract tourists, and enrich our community.
column9: > How effective is the arts council?
column17: > In 2010 the arts council working with local artists fostered over 315 days of art programs.

column1: The Impact

School budgets are major topic in every community. Important programs such as the art education are often in danger of being cut as they are viewed as ""extra"" program.  In truth, arts education impacts core learning skills as a national study found that students engaged in the arts are  4 times more likely to be involved in the arts and sciences.  In a state where almost 20% of the people are illiterate the arts are key to education as students involved in the arts are also four times more likely to excel in reading.

Sadly, here in Mississippi we are no exception.  This year, our governor proposed to cut funding to the arts by  20%.  Our goal is simple: to provide as many children with opportunities to interact with the arts as possible.  You can help our small art council impact the lives of children in the Oxford, Mississippi/ Lafayette County area with an after school art camp taught by local artist and teacher, Andi Bedsworth.  The art projects will be ones that don't require a lot of expensive materials.  The program is design to teach children how to make art trading cards.  Small works for art the size of baseball cards with objects from around their home. This will allow them to continue to create and be inspired after they leave camp.
<h3>What We Need &amp
Your donation is 100% tax deductible (as allowed by law). Donations will be used to pay for supplies and the artist who teaches the class.
$10- You will receive a thank you card created by one of our campers
$25- You will receive a special thanks on the online art gallery
$50- You will receive a personalized trading card made by a camper
$100-  You will receive a special piece of art made by the teacher of the camp
Other Ways You Can Help
Share this link with all your friends.  This is the most important step.  Our goal is only $500.
Of course if you happen to run an art supply store, office supply store, or would like to donate supplies that will be used for free art camps we can use:
pencils, regular and colored
cardstock and colored paper,
glue,
paint,
small paint brushes,
markers,
scrapbook supplies
However, with your help, we can raise much much more.

Description:
Since
1949 with the crowning of the first Miss York County, the York County
Pageants Program has been a resource by which young women in the
state of Pennsylvania, and most notably York county, to obtain
scholarship money and notoriety to help achieve their goals in life.
In
1986 the program was reorganized by Shana and Jerry Garling, along
with several volunteers.  These re-organizational efforts led to the
addition of the first Miss Susquehanna Valley title being awarded in
1993, followed by the first Miss White Rose City title in 2001.  In
2005 the addition of the York County Outstanding Teen was added,
followed by Susquehanna Valley Outstanding Teen in 2010, and finally
White Rose City Outstanding Teen in 2011.
As
a result of the reorganization efforts, now in their 66th year of
operation, 6 young women (3 Miss and 3 Teen) are given the
opportunity to be crowned in front of approximately 200-500 patrons
(depending on the venue used that particular year), advancing to
become a Miss Pennsylvania hopeful (www.misspa.org),
with the ultimate goal of becoming Miss America.  The program has
also been able to provide thousands of dollars in scholarships to
young women in South Central Pennsylvania.
In
addition to being given the chance to win a title from the York
County Program, the winning titleholders are then tasked with
promoting their individual platforms each year.  These platforms have
ranged from Domestic Violence Awareness, Global Health Now, childhood
literacy, and numerous other topics.
Each
year the program gives approximately $4,000 to Miss York County, and
$1,800 is split between Miss Susquehanna Valley and Miss White Rose
City.  The scholarship funds given to these three titles alone are
currently the result of one generous donor, who has been apart of the
program since the early 90s.
Not
only has this one donor given scholarship money to these title
holders just for winning their titles, but they also give out money
to the highest scoring interview contestants.
Aside
from these scholarship awards the program also gives out awards for
Teen Choice, Talent, etc. that are supported by other local donors.
What
we are asking for:
The
program is grateful and will always be grateful for the current
contributions of its sponsors and patrons, however, the program does
understand that times change, and with ever changing economic
conditions, changes to current contributions can change for future
needs.
The pageant program has set a goal of $6,500.00 as
it prepares to organize its 67<sup>th</sup>
annual pageant program, in York, Pennsylvania.
Here
is a general outline of where the money would be going:
<li>
Facility
rental
– approximately $2,500
<li>
Crowns
– approximately per year for 3 Miss and 3 Teen winners
<li>
Awards
(trophies, flowers) - approximately $1,000
<li>
Program
books
– approximately $1000
<li>
Franchise
fees
– approximately $800
Any
funds that are received beyond the $6,500 mark would be used
primarily to add to the scholarship awards that are currently
offered, as well as to costs associated with the operations of the
pageant: materials creation, helping to expand the program's reach in

the community, etc.

","Description:
Since
1949 with the crowning of the first Miss York County, the York County
Pageants Program has been a resource by which young women in the
state of Pennsylvania, and most notably York county, to obtain
scholarship money and notoriety to help achieve their goals in life.
In
1986 the program was reorganized by Shana and Jerry Garling, along
with several volunteers.  These re-organizational efforts led to the
addition of the first Miss Susquehanna Valley title being awarded in
1993, followed by the first Miss White Rose City title in 2001.  In
2005 the addition of the York County Outstanding Teen was added,
followed by Susquehanna Valley Outstanding Teen in 2010, and finally
White Rose City Outstanding Teen in 2011.
As
a result of the reorganization efforts, now in their 66th year of
operation, 6 young women (3 Miss and 3 Teen) are given the
opportunity to be crowned in front of approximately 200-500 patrons
(depending on the venue used that particular year), advancing to
become a Miss Pennsylvania hopeful (www.misspa.org),
with the ultimate goal of becoming Miss America.  The program has
also been able to provide thousands of dollars in scholarships to
young women in South Central Pennsylvania.
In
addition to being given the chance to win a title from the York
County Program, the winning titleholders are then tasked with
promoting their individual platforms each year.  These platforms have
ranged from Domestic Violence Awareness, Global Health Now, childhood
literacy, and numerous other topics.
Each
year the program gives approximately $4,000 to Miss York County, and
$1,800 is split between Miss Susquehanna Valley and Miss White Rose
City.  The scholarship funds given to these three titles alone are
currently the result of one generous donor, who has been apart of the
program since the early 90s.
Not
only has this one donor given scholarship money to these title
holders just for winning their titles, but they also give out money
to the highest scoring interview contestants.
Aside
from these scholarship awards the program also gives out awards for
Teen Choice, Talent, etc. that are supported by other local donors.
What
we are asking for:
The
program is grateful and will always be grateful for the current
contributions of its sponsors and patrons, however, the program does
understand that times change, and with ever changing economic
conditions, changes to current contributions can change for future
needs.
The pageant program has set a goal of $6,500.00 as
it prepares to organize its 67th
annual pageant program, in York, Pennsylvania.
Here
is a general outline of where the money would be going:
Facility
rental
– approximately $2,500
Crowns
($750) and sashes ($450)
– approximately  per year for 3 Miss and 3 Teen winners
Awards
(trophies, flowers) -  approximately $1,000
Program
books
– approximately $1000
Franchise
fees
– approximately $800
Any
funds that are received beyond the $6,500 mark would be used
primarily to add to the scholarship awards that are currently
offered, as well as to costs associated with the operations of the
pageant: materials creation, helping to expand the program's reach in
the community, etc.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","York, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/support-the-york-county-pageants-program/pica

Help Noah Palmer-Licht get to Rome, Italy!

Hello friends!

 Noah is an architecture student at The University of North Carolina At Charlotte, He has been accepted to study in Rome, Italy for 5 weeks this summer. 

Noah is a Dean's List student who is well respected in the school of Architecture. He is the only undergraduate student who was asked to be a Teaching Assistant in the department. 

The program in Rome will allow Noah the amazing opportunity to see the buildings he as been studying and create new works of his own. It will also afford him the opportunity to graduate earlier, based on the credits he will accrue during this program. 

We need to get him at least $3000.00 to make this trip a reality. Unfortunately, time is of the essence. We need to have this money together by April 28th.

About
Hi,
my name is Megan Butler and I was born and raised on the Navajo Nation in Tuba
City, Arizona. Both my parents are full Navajo making me full Navajo. I just graduated with a Bachelors in Sociology at Brigham Young University in Provo,
Utah. I currently work at the Provo MTC Dining, which I really enjoy. Since finishing school last week I became the second in my family history to earn a degree. I am SO incredibly excited!
In
May I will be going to Mbale, Uganda to work on a community outreach project
with HELP International. HELP International allows for community members to
become self-sufficient instead of being dependent on others by incorporating
these community outreach projects. It will be my job to help them grow to be
self-sufficient. These projects are designed to target specific community

challenges and I will be working with HIV/AIDS patients. I am making one last push to raise money for my internship so I would really appreciate all the help I could get. 

This is also a perfect opportunity for me to learn about starting my own non-profit organization. I have a burning desire to start a non-profit on the Navajo Nation.
This
project will include...
<ol>
<li>educating
at risk people or people already living with HIV/AIDS through workshops
and teach how to reduce the spread and maintain a healthy lifestyle
<li>working
with HIV support groups, supporting ""AIDS orphans"", or oprhaned
children due to HIV/AIDS,
<li>addressing
HIV/AIDS stigma in the community,
<li>and
encouraging community members to be regularly tested for HIV/AIDS.
This
is my dream internship. It is also helping me reach my long term goal of
becoming a Podiatric Surgeon specializing in diabetic limb salvage. There is a
great need for diabetic specialists on the Navajo Nation. Last year I began the
long and rigorous road to medical school. I can check a Bachelor's degree and
an amazing internship off my list but I still need to take my science classes
for the MCAT.
I
realize this is going to be a long and difficult road but I know it will be
worth it and I would love your help along the way. It is my dream to be a
surgeon and this internship will help me in that direction but I cannot do it

by myself. So again, I would love your support in helping me achieve my goals.

This is my last push to fundraise for my project. I would really appreciate anything you could help me with including any sort of support.
What
I need...
I
will need help paying for the rest of my program fees amounting to $3,000. These HELP International
program fees go directly to the communities and their individual projects. The
program provides most weekly meals but there are a couple days as well as every
lunch not provided because interns are usually busy with their projects during
the day and exploring on weekends.
Those
of you who know me personally know that I love to travel. It is my passion to
learn about other cultures and see the beauty in all things as well as help
people. It will be my pleasure to keep weekly updates in my experiences through
my blog.

http://ugandalandofbeauty.blogspot.com/ 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can contribute and it doesn't have to be financially. You could spread the word about HELP International and the projects they are doing. Don't forget to tell people about Indiegogo and their contributions to my project. 

Thank you so much!!

Tout récemment 18 ans avec mon BAC en
poche, l'envie d'aller à la rencontre de  cultures et plus
particulièrement l'Australienne s'ouvre à mon horizon.
La possibilité de marier la
découverte d'une nouvelle culture et l'apprentissage de l'anglais est devenue
pour moi un projet qui me tiens à cœur et passionne mes expectatives de future.
Consciente de l'enjeu majeur
qui représente la parfaite connaissance de l'anglais à l'heure
actuelle, je me fixe comme objectif 6 mois de cours intensives
pour accomplir mon propos.
Votre participation à mon projet sera
uniquement pour financer mon école.
Pendant les deux précédents années
j'ai eu la possibilité grâce à du Baby Sitting d'économiser une bonne
partie de mon billet d'avion.
J'ai la chance aussi de compter
avec quelqu'un de ma famille qui habite à Brisbane (ville dans laquelle je
souhaite aller étudier) qui va m'accueillir chez lui avec sa femme et son
enfant.
Bien évidement l'expérience de
travailler en tant qu'étudiant aussi fait partie de ce projet car nous le
savons tous l'argent est non seulement nécessaire mais  importante
pour notre quotidien,
Avec un Père Colombien et une mere
Espagnole, dès mon petite enfance j'ai étais  baignée  par les belles
tonalités de l espagnol, et oui je suis bilingue et très fière de l'être
En 2014 pendant les vacances j'ai eu
la possibilité de passer mon diplôme BAFA à afin d'acquérir d'autres outils et
expériences de vie et travail
Avec mon bac pro mode acquis cette année, je me dirige aussi vers le design d'intérieur.
Pleine d'espoir pour l'accomplissement de ce projet, j'ai décidée de demander de l'aide via cet outil de crowfounding, car je tiens vraiment à pouvoir le réaliser.
Mon envie, et mon engagement, sont là, mon billet d'avion réservé aussi...

Le départ prévue pour le milieu du mois de septembre, je vous encourage vivement a participer pour pouvoir donner vie à ce projet, mon projet dont vous serais fier dans quelques mois... 

« when finally I will
sing in english » :)
Toujours déterminée dans mes projets, avec la préparation de ce voyage en cours, mon expectative grandit jour après jour.
N'hésitez pas a faire passer mon projet à d'autres en vue de son bon aboutissement.
Les dépenses de mon projet :
-
25 leçons de 60 minutes
-
24 semaines du 28.09.2015 au 11.03.2016 : 340 AUD / SEMAINE
-  Frais d'inscription : 220 AUD
-  Matériel des cours : 336 AUD
-  Assurance maladie OSHC : 350 AUD
TOTAL 9066 AUD
-  VISA étudiant : 500 euros
TOTAL 9066 AUD + 500 euros visa (
6600 euros environs)
Merci à tous et à toutes.
Sachez que vous pouvez participer à cette aide en mettant à partir de 10e et jusqu'au maximum de votre choix et possibilité.
big kisses
Sofia
Acabando de cumplir mis 18 años y con mi bachillerato
en el bolsillo, el deseo de conocer nuevas culturas y más particularmente la
Australiana se abre hacia mis horizontes.
<span><span>La posibilidad de descubrir
una nueva cultura y aprender al mismo tiempo el inglés se ha convertido en un proyecto que me interesa muchísimo y apasiona mis futuras expectativas.
<span>Consciente de la
importancia que representa actualmente el perfecto conocimiento del inglés, desearía
realizar 6 meses de cursos intensivos para lograr mi objetivo.
Vuestra participación a mi proyecto seria únicamente
para financiar mis estudios.
<span>Los dos últimos años, tuve la posibilidad gracias a un
trabajo de Baby Sitting de ahorrar una buena parte de mi billete de avión.
<span>Tengo también la suerte
de contar con alguien de mi familia en Brisbane (ciudad a donde deseo ir a
estudiar) que va a acogerme en su casa con su mujer y su hijo.
<span>Evidentemente el deseo de
trabajar al mismo tiempo que mis estudios, hace parte de mi proyecto,
porque como todos y todas sabemos el dinero es necesario para avanzar hoy en día.
Con un padre Colombiano y una madre Española, desde
pequeña escuché las bellas tonalidades de la lengua Española, y hoy por
hoy estoy muy orgullosa de poder ser bilingüe.
<span><span>En 2014 durante mis vacaciones
realice los cursos para obtener mi diploma BAFA (diploma para poder
trabajar con niños) con el fin de adquirir otras herramientas y experiencias de
vida y trabajo
<span>Con mi bachillerato
especializado en la moda, me gustaría dirigirme en un futuro hacia el diseño de
interiores.
<span>Llena de esperanza en que
mi proyecto se haga realidad, decidí pedir ayuda a través de este sistema, el
crowfounding, porque verdaderamente deseo que se cumpla.
<span>Con mi billete
de avión reservado, el viaje previsto para
mediados de septiembre, os animo a participar para así ayudarme a dar vida a
este proyecto, mi proyecto, del que no

lo dudéis estaré orgullosa dentro de algunos meses …
« when finally I will
sing in english » :)
<span>Determinada en mis
proyectos, mi expectativa de que se haga realidad crece día tras día, su
preparación ya esta en proceso … ayúdame enviando esta información a otras
personas que creas puedan ser participes de esta bonita aventura y colaborar con mi viaje de estudios.
Los costos de mi proyecto :
-
25 lecciones de 60 minutes
-
24 semanas del 28.09.2015 al 11.03.2016 : 340 AUD / SEMANA
-  Inscription : 220 AUD
-  Materiales para los cursos : 336 AUD
-  Seguridad social OSHC : 350 AUD
TOTAL 9066 AUD
-  VISA estudiante : 500 euros
TOTAL 9066 AUD + 500 euros visa (
6600 euros aproximadamente)
Gracias a todos y a todas.
En esta plataforma
su contribución puede ir desde 10e hasta el máximo  sus deseos y posibilidades
big kisses
Sofía

Welcome to the Camel Company Alumni Scholarship Fund (CCASF) Fundraising Page!

7 January Update

To date, your contributions to CCASF during this drive have raised $350. Overall, the CCASF has raised over $3,000 in pursuit of its $25,000 endowment goal.

Thanks!

History

Established in 2011 by class of 1997 Camel Company ROTC commissioned officers Brett McCreight, Bryan Kirk and Christopher Samples, the Camel Company Alumni Scholarship Fund was the product of their desire to give back to Campbell University and the ROTC department which united them as life-long friends.

Mission

CCASF rewards deserving sophomore and junior cadets with direct aid scholarships in order to assist cadets with meeting their financial obligations.

Way Ahead

As the Department of Defense cycles through another dip in overall funding, CCASF provides a direct link from alumni to young cadets to mitigate the loss of these scholarship monies.

CCASF's short term goal for 1 February 2014 is to reach $1,000 in base donations for the 2014-2015 Scholarship Award period. Awards will be presented in April 2014 at Campbell University's ROTC awards program.

The long term goal for CCASF is to reach $25,000 in overall donations. Once CCASF has reached $25,000 in overall donations, CCASF will transition to a self-generating $1,000 yearly endowment to the ROTC department indefinitely.

Donations above and beyond $25,000 will allow the leadership of CCASF to react more  tangibly to the needs of the department and its cadets. Donations could be used, for example, to assist with department fund-raising or facilitate department purchases (uniforms for Ranger Challenge, Raiders, etc). More importantly, these funds could be directed to assist cadets in need during emergency situations.

For example, while McCreight served as Executive Officer at the ROTC department at Virginia State University, the alumni scholarship board there made frequent donations to cadets in need, due to personal hardship (house fire, divorce, etc.). That is the sort of relevant, responsive scholarship fund we want to establish.

To date, CCASF has successfully given $2,000 in scholarships to deserving ROTC cadets over the past two school years. 

All funds received will be applied to the CCASF donations for the 2014-2015 school year, funds received in excess of $1,000 will be placed in the endowment to mature. 

Past Donors

Thanks to Brett McCreight, Bryan Kirk, Bracken Murphy, Chris Samples, and Special Forces Association Chapter 62 (Southern Pines) for their donations during our first two years of giving!

Spread the word!

We would sincerely appreciate it if you would forward the link to
this site to any Campbell grads and folks you think would support our

efforts here.

Thanks for helping us to help the future leaders of the Army.

Overall, the CCASF has raised over $3,000 in pursuit of its $25,000 endowment goal. Thanks!HistoryEstablished in 2011 by class of 1997 Camel Company ROTC commissioned officers Brett McCreight, Bryan Kirk and Christopher Samples, the Camel Company Alumni Scholarship Fund was the product of their desire to give back to Campbell University and the ROTC department which united them as life-long friends. MissionCCASF rewards deserving sophomore and junior cadets with direct aid scholarships in order to assist cadets with meeting their financial obligations.Way Ahead As the Department of Defense cycles through another dip in overall funding, CCASF provides a direct link from alumni to young cadets to mitigate the loss of these scholarship monies. CCASF's short term goal for 1 February 2014 is to reach $1,000 in base donations for the 2014-2015 Scholarship Award period. Awards will be presented in April 2014 at Campbell University's ROTC awards program. The long term goal for CCASF is to reach $25,000 in overall donations. Once CCASF has reached $25,000 in overall donations, CCASF will transition to a self-generating $1,000 yearly endowment to the ROTC department indefinitely. Donations above and beyond $25,000 will allow the leadership of CCASF to react more  tangibly to the needs of the department and its cadets. Donations could be used, for example, to assist with department fund-raising or facilitate department purchases (uniforms for Ranger Challenge, Raiders, etc). More importantly, these funds could be directed to assist cadets in need during emergency situations. For example, while McCreight served as Executive Officer at the ROTC department at Virginia State University, the alumni scholarship board there made frequent donations to cadets in need, due to personal hardship (house fire, divorce, etc.). That is the sort of relevant, responsive scholarship fund we want to establish. To date, CCASF has successfully given $2,000 in scholarships to deserving ROTC cadets over the past two school years. All funds received will be applied to the CCASF donations for the 2014-2015 school year, funds received in excess of $1,000 will be placed in the endowment to mature. Past DonorsThanks to Brett McCreight, Bryan Kirk, Bracken Murphy, Chris Samples, and Special Forces Association Chapter 62 (Southern Pines) for their donations during our first two years of giving!Spread the word!We would sincerely appreciate it if you would forward the link to
this site to any Campbell grads and folks you think would support our
efforts here.Thanks for helping us to help the future leaders of the Army.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Buies Creek, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/camel-company-alumni-scholarship-fund-ccasf/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
Why DreamMaker
Matters
You can support many generations
of America’s
finest young men and women in service to our country with a single, 100% tax
deductible gift this year.
Your gift will help to create a
perpetual, self-renewing fund unlike any other scholarship fund in America. The DreamMaker
Honor Fund truly earns the often-abused description of “Unique”. You’ll see why
when you view the video below.
The DreamMaker Honor Fund will
enable generations of these outstanding future leaders to earn their appointments
to their choice of US Military Service Academies without regard to their
family’s financial resources.
The Greystone Class of 2015 is
asking each of their families to set a goal of raising $5000 from each family’s
network of relatives, friends, business associates, and others. The Greystone
Board of Directors, along with a group of 70+ Friends of Greystone, is each
committed to a goal of raising $5000 from their networks of friends, family,
business associates, former military colleagues, and others.
Also, by posting this project on
IndieGogo, people around the world who understand the value of having the
highest quality young men and women serving in leadership positions in the US military
will have an opportunity to support their convictions directly through
contributions to the DreamMaker Honor Fund. A campaign that is successful at
reaching these very achievable individual goals will meet or exceed the goal of
raising $268,000.
As you watch this short video created by the Greystone class
of 2015 you will see why your contribution to this Fund will do far, far more
than simply help one or two students with financial needs. It will create a
self-renewing, perpetual fund in support of future Greystone classes, and
future generations of dedicated US Military officers.
This video will explain in the
students’ own words how this will be achieved, and why it is their personal
commitment that will guarantee the DreamMaker Honor Fund’s perpetuity. After
watching the video, if you would like to have more information, we’ve posted a
detailed discussion below. And if you still have questions, please contact
Greystone by phone or email. We are at your service.
http://youtu.be/37Yd1pf1NSQ
Why Greystone’s DreamMaker Honor Fund Should Be A Priority Contribution
Students come to Greystone after they have already applied
for an appointment to one of the five US Military Service Academies, and
received one or more nominations, but have been turned down. They have chosen
not to accept defeat, and have turned to the Greystone Program to empower them
to earn their appointment on the second try.
In the Greystone program’s ten years, 86% of Greystone
students have earned their appointments, and an additional 12% have earned full
ROTC scholarships to leading universities around the country. All have gone on
to serve with distinction.
The DreamMaker Honor Fund at
Greystone Preparatory School is designed to make
it possible for these young men and women who will not give up, and who are
determined to earn an appointment to their choice of the US Military Service
Academies to do so without regard to their family’s ability to pay.
As Greystone students have just explained, through a unique
financial mechanism available only to successful students at the five US Military
Service Academies, your 100% tax deductable contribution will be replenished
year after year, supporting not just one student with financial needs, but
generations of Greystone students whose driving ambition is to serve their
country.
If you are in a position to make a financial contribution to
any worthwhile cause this year, please consider how much further your money
will go in the Greystone DreamMaker Honor Fund,
and the kind of young men and women whose dreams you will be supporting.
DreamMaker Honor Fund
&amp
If you have ever made a charitable contribution to a
scholarship fund, you know that while 100% of such a gift is always
tax-deductable, the fund itself must be very large in order to generate significant
revenues.
For example, in today’s financial climate, a gift of $1
Million can be expected to generate @ $5000 per year for use by the scholarship
fund. And once that $5000 is given to one or more recipients, it is gone
forever. The $1 Million may stay intact and generate income each year that can
be used for scholarships, but every time that new income is given to a student
it is also gone. Conventional scholarship funds can never grow without added
external contributions, and in fact will usually shrink in value over time
because of inflation, which is why college scholarship funds are continually going
to alumni and asking for contributions.
The DreamMaker Honor Fund will
never be depleted, and in fact it will grow over the years as successive classes
raise additional funds, which are then repaid by those classes as they reach
Third-Year status at the Academies. This means that unlike any other
scholarship fund The DreamMaker Honor Fund
will be self-sustaining.
How The Numbers Work
A gift of any size that you give to the DreamMaker Honor Fund at Greystone Preparatory
school will have far greater impact than a
conventional donation. For one thing, you will not have to give $1 Million in
order to generate $5000 in scholarship funds. A gift of $5000 will generate
$5000 in scholarship funds immediately, and then that $5000 will be returned to
the DreamMaker Honor Fund by its recipient to
be given again and again to future generations of Greystone students. A gift of
$5000 given in 2014 will generate $35,000 in scholarship funds over the next 10
years, and $50,000 in scholarship funds every decade thereafter.
And by the way, we are using $5000 only as an example. A
gift of $500 will generate $3,500 in scholarship grants over the next ten
years, and $5,000 in scholarship grants over each succeeding decade.
No gift is too small to have a big multiplier effect!
How The DreamMaker Honor Fund Works – And Why It Is Unique
Greystone is a 501.c.3 registered non-profit so all
contributions are 100% tax-deductable, Anyone who needs to make a charitable
donation to reduce their 2014 taxes can choose the DreamMaker
Honor Fund at Greystone with confidence.
Unlike any other scholarship fund anywhere, where available
funds are awarded to a student one time and then are gone, DreamMaker Honor Fund contribution will be used
again and again to benefit both current and future generations of students with
a burning desire to earn their US Military Service Academy appointment.
This is possible because any Greystone student who takes a
Grant (not a loan!) from DreamMaker Honor Fund
promises on their honor to make a completely voluntary donation, in an amount
that they alone decide, back to DreamMaker Honor Fund
at the end of their Third Year in the Academy.
As an example, if a member of the Class of 2015 receives a
$5000 grant from DreamMaker Honor Fund they
promise on their honor to make a contribution of at least $5000 back to DreamMaker Honor
Fund out of the funds made available to them at the end of their 3<sup>rd</sup>
year.
Since this student will not be re-paying a loan, and since
they are under no legal obligation to pay back the DreamMaker
Honor Fund grant they receive but are making a completely voluntary and
independent contribution to the DreamMaker Honor Fund
in an amount that they alone
determine, this contribution will count as a deductable charitable contribution
that can be applied to their own tax obligations in their first year as an
Academy graduate serving in the field or the fleet.
DreamMaker Honor Fund
Grants Are Not Just To Address Financial Hardship
The DreamMaker Honor Fund is
not limited to students whose family’s financial need makes it imperative that
they receive a grant. Every year a Grants Committee composed of Class Officers
and members of the Greystone Board of directors will prioritize money available
from the DreamMaker Honor Fund as follows:
Students with severe financial need will be in the priority
group for grants from the DreamMaker Honor Fund.
The needs of these students will be met first. They will be classified as the
Priority Financial Need Group, and the Grants Committee will allocate funds to
these students based on the recommendations of Schreiner University’s
Financial Aid Office to ensure that they have 100% of the funds they need to
complete the Greystone program and earn their academy appointment
However, once the needs of the priority group are taken care
of, then ANY Greystone student is eligible to ask for a grant that will let
them shoulder more of the financial responsibility of the Greystone program
themselves. These students will be classified as the Merit Grant Group, and the
Grants Committee will consider each application on its merits, and will fund
each Grant based on the funds available, and on the short letter of application
that each student will be asked to write.
Although the families of students in the Merit Grant Group
have been able to ensure that their son or daughter has sufficient funds to
complete the Greystone program and earn their Academy appointment, members of
the Class of 2015, and of future classes, are becoming leaders who know the
meaning of taking personal responsibility. Asking for a Merit Grant to be
applied against their educational costs, thereby reducing the burden on their
families, is a responsibility that each member of the Class of 2015 has eagerly
accepted.
The Role Of The
Greater Greystone Family
All that remains is for each member of the Greystone family
to do their part in achieving the goal of raising enough money to bring the DreamMaker Honor Fund to a level where it can meet
all of its goals.
The Staff and Board of Greystone will be in close touch with
everyone working to meet their individual goals to find out how we can help. We
can write letters, make calls, draft press releases, identify potential donors
in your communities, and call on our extensive network of serving and retired
Military as well as Greystone graduates still at the Academies or graduated and
serving around the world for assistance.
We believe in our Class of 2015, and in their families, and
in the community of friends that the Greystone program has been blessed with
through the years.
Working together we will not fail.

Short Summary

Started in 2010 by high school students Ian and Lara Olsson, Letters for Better is an organization dedicated to collaborating with South Floridian and Caribbean communities to promote literacy.  Our objectives are to donate used books to areas in need. Not only that, but we read our collected books to children, teens, and adults in the area. We strive to raise awareness of the importance of literature. 

In the 2011-12 school year, Letters for Better collected over 2,000 books from hundreds of different donors, books ranging from pre-school level to the great classics. We then donated these books in March 2012 to Cypress Elementary School in Pompano, FL, which had a library consisting of 200 books. With our donation, the school's library multiplied by 11. 

In the 2012-2013 school year, Letters for Better grew stronger, collecting over 2,700 books. The books were donated to Kelsey L. Pharr Elementary School in Liberty City, Miami. In the latter half of 2013, Letters for Better continued books drives and collected over 3,000 books, which have been donated to community centers, homeless shelters, and libraries throughout South Florida.  

The effects of Letters for Better have been outstanding, but now we want to extend the organization and its message beyond United States borders.  After weeks of research, we have chosen various Carribbean schools to donate the remaining books we have, including three schools in Puerto Rico. The schools are in the San Juan, Carolina, and Majaguez communities.
column7: What You Get In Return
column8: >In April of 2014, we, 6 Letters for Better members, plan to travel to Puerto Rico. These 5,000 dollars will cover hotel expenses, flight expenses, and book transportation. The book transportation itself will
column10: >For every 15 dollars you donate, you will receive a Letters for Better bookmark: complemented with a mystery literary quote and Letters for Better organization pictures. For every 30 dollar donation you will also receive a mystery book along with the Letters for Better bookmark.
column11:
>If we don't reach our goal, the funds collected will solely be used for future organization activities. 

The Impact

Your generous contribution will help spread literacy in Puerto Rico and ensure the vitality of future projects of our organization. The contribution will impact more than 500 children in Puerto Rico. This trip will set as a precedent to all future international book donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are also other ways to collaborate with Letters for Better! We are always looking for volunteers and any used books you may have at home. Below is our contact information. 

E-mail: lettersforbetter@gmail.com

>Facebook page: facebook.com/Lettersforbetter

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a="""">Dear Friend(s) of Ashe Family Literacy,

Thank you so much for your recent donation. Because of you and your generosity, Ashe Family Literacy will be able to continue serving the educational needs of parents and children in 2014. We are excited at the response our Indiegogo campaign has generated
column2: however, since we launched the campaign, it has been brought to our attention that this form of fundraising has ramifications beyond those we intended, and we have been advised to close the campaign at this point.

column1: Please be assured that your donations will go directly to Ashe Family Literacy and be used exclusively for the purpose we stated: to pay a living wage to our highly qualified early childhood educator. This will enable the parents of preschool children who have the need and the initiative to complete their secondary education to achieve this goal, and will prepare their children to enter school ready to learn and to succeed. The families who benefit from this program thank you sincerely for this opportunity.
Thank you for your support of Indiegogo and its efforts to help individuals and organizations in raising funds to continue their good works and make the world better every day.
Best wishes for the holidays!

Short Summary

YD-360 is a Messianic Youth Group that
believes in spreading the gospel in every encounter and interaction. Based in
Fort Lauderdale, Florida, YD-360 moves under the guidance of Hashem (G-D) to help other
thoughout the community.
<ul>
<li style=""text-align: justify
<i>In the <b>Dominican
Republic almost half of the nation's population lives under the
poverty line and thus there is a need for volunteers to come to the nation. With a Population of 9.4 million people, the Poverty
Level is 42.3 %. Many
parts of the Dominican Republic are not developed and there is a need for
extensive work. What they are in drastic need of is schools and community
centers.  The Dominican Republic had identified early childhood
education as a strategy to reducing poverty. However primary completion
rate is only 80 percent. Lack of access to education is a
contributing cause. <b>Statistics show that 25 percent of young children do
not have access to one year of pre-primary educational and this situation is
worse among the poorest population.
<li style=""text-align: justify
assist a population in receiving much needed educational
resources. It will help other who do not have access to a building to have
school or access to much needed educational resources. We need your help
so that we can help other earn an education.
What We Need &
<ul>
<li>Through
partnering with an international organization YD-360 has the opportunity to assist them in
building schools in the Dominican Republic. The majority of the funds
raised goes toward purchasing building supplies (Cement, Blocks, Metal bar supports) and other supplies) that will
be used directly in the construction of the school project.The
remainder of the funding will assist in acquiring airfare, housing and
other travel amenities. Rest assured that this is no glamour project. Our
work day will be from 6:00
AM
to 6:00 PM. We will be
living in tents and cooking over and open fire. This will definitely not
be a vacation trip.
<li>We believe that
this trip will broaden our cultural perspectives as well as well as our
horizons. We believe that this trip will not only build character but give
us the opportunity to work with over 500 youth from around the world who
will also be working with us to build schools in the Dominican Republic.  This is a 10 day experience that we will
remember for a lifetime.
<li>If we don’t reach
our goal we will still donate the monies raised to the cause. Since we
believe that education and building school in the Dominican Republic is

needed in the Dominican Republic and we believe that we need to invest our

the world to construct various buildings. While our primary construction

","Short SummaryYD-360 is a Messianic Youth Group that
believes in spreading the gospel in every encounter and interaction. Based in
Fort Lauderdale, Florida, YD-360 moves under the guidance of Hashem (G-D) to help other
thoughout the community.
In the Dominican
Republic almost half of the nation's population lives under the
poverty line and thus there is a need for volunteers to come to the nation. With a Population of 9.4 million people, the Poverty
Level is 42.3 %. Many
parts of the Dominican Republic are not developed and there is a need for
extensive work. What they are in drastic need of is schools and community
centers.  The Dominican Republic had identified early childhood
education as a strategy to reducing poverty. However primary completion
rate is only 80 percent. Lack of access to education is a
contributing cause. Statistics show that 25 percent of young children do
not have access to one year of pre-primary educational and this situation is
worse among the poorest population.
The school will
assist a population in receiving much needed educational
resources. It will help other who do not have access to a building to have
school or access to much needed educational resources. We need your help
so that we can help other earn an education.
What We Need & What You Get
Through
partnering with an international organization YD-360 has the opportunity to assist them in
building schools in the Dominican Republic. The majority of the funds
raised goes toward purchasing building supplies (Cement, Blocks, Metal bar supports) and other supplies) that will
be used directly in the construction of the school project.The
remainder of the funding will assist in acquiring airfare, housing and
other travel amenities. Rest assured that this is no glamour project. Our
work day will be from 6:00
AM
to 6:00 PM. We will be
living in tents and cooking over and open fire. This will definitely not
be a vacation trip.
We believe that
this trip will broaden our cultural perspectives as well as well as our
horizons. We believe that this trip will not only build character but give
us the opportunity to work with over 500 youth from around the world who
will also be working with us to build schools in the Dominican Republic.  This is a 10 day experience that we will
remember for a lifetime.
If we don’t reach
our goal we will still donate the monies raised to the cause. Since we
believe that education and building school in the Dominican Republic is
important, we intent to support this cause with any resources that we
raise so your donation will support the school building project even if we
can’t participate.
The Impact
Schools are
needed in the Dominican Republic and we believe that we need to invest our
time, resources and efforts in helping others earn an education. With the
limited number of schools available help us help other earn and education by
assisting us as we build a school that will educate generations of young
people.

Short Summary

Duke/Durham Saves is a student run organization dedicated to promoting financial literacy and wealth building. While we try to work with as many constituent bases as possible, we focus on Duke students, Durham youth, and individuals in the lower and middle class who may not have a savings account. We operate in many facets at Duke including teaching a class on Personal Finance, partnering with the Center for Advanced Hindsight run by Dan Ariely to attach metrics to our work, and the Duke Annual Fund and Alumni Affairs to make the transition to the working world easier for Duke alumni. We also partner with the Financial Aid office to run the PersonalFinance@Duke initiative and work with students on budgeting financial aid lump sum payments.

Within the Durham community, we work with the Boys and Girls Club to play the ""Investing"" game with and teach financial literacy to over 150 students. We will also interact with students' parents to provide family support that will aid in bolstering financial independence and education. We work with both the Self-Help Credit Union and Duke Credit Union to provide specialized savings accounts that we have negotiated with low minimum balances, opening charges, and reduced fees. We augment these savings accounts with automatic transfer policies and CDs as well as other investment vehicles that may support our population.

As we are a young organization, we currently have many other projects in the pipeline to continuously expand our proven efforts. In the coming months, we are trying to enter the Durham Public Schools to mentor children and use financial literacy as a means to complement math learning in a fun and constructive environment. We are working with the Alumni Office to create a ""Twitter Chat"" for alumni so that we can answer common questions about personal finance including couponing, finding apartments in new cities, and credit and investments. We are also trying to write a weekly column in The Chronicle, the Duke University independent newspaper. Finally, we are looking to host a luncheon focused on the community development activities of Self-Help and a larger conference whereby we can bring together some of the great minds in North Carolina regarding poverty alleviation to engage in frank and interesting discussions regarding different policies and their success. We are hoping to host this conference in April during Financial Literacy Month.
<h3>What We Need &amp

Funding is critical to our success at impacting decisions by our constituents. One of the greatest assets of our organization is our flexibility and limited overhead which allows us to distribute funds towards productive and cost-effective measures. Since we are a charitable organization and trying to maximize impact, we are only offering prizes for donations over $20 and those will be more towards promoting our organization than rewards for donations. We hope you understand our rationale and still support our cause.  We have numerous projects in the pipeline currently:
<ul>
<li>Provide matching grants to youth and parents through our partnership with the Boys &amp
column2: Girls Club. We are hoping to provide $10 donations that will accompany a $5-10 investment and enrollment in an automatic savings plan. We are hoping to reach over 400 youth using this program by May 2014.

column1: • Develop mobile and online games that we can use to help students and adults make more informed financial decisions. One example is a dynamic game involving negotiating a salary or for an item such as a house or a car with responses differing based on your choices.
• Create tips and online lesson plans based on the Duke House Course on personal finance to be placed on our website and various other outlets.
• Expand the reach of the PersonalFinance@Duke website.
• Create a more expansive website to draw in more users.
• Act as ""quarterback"" to local organizations dedicated to alleviating poverty and providing financial education.
We are setting up several perks that we think will entice more people to join in our campaign:
<ul>
• Each person that donates over $20 will receive a pair of Duke/Durham Saves green sunglasses.
• First 20 people to donate over $50 receive the online personal finance class developed by our founder free.
• Next 50 people to donate over $50 receive the online personal finance class at a 50% discount.

• Each person that donates over $100 will receive an informational packet about and letter from a child whose matching grant you have funded. This packet will come once this project starts. He/She will also receive our Duke/Durham Saves sunglasses and the course materials from our class.
• Each person that donates over $500 will receive our glasses, the informational packet and letter, and an online personal finance class (valued at $25).
The Impact

The Duke/Durham Saves campaign has the potential to materially affect both the Duke and Durham populations. This project increases beneficial relationships between not only students and local youth but also between Duke and our numerous partner organizations. It allows us to help build confidence in the community and provide meaningful change through both financial literacy programs and ""point of impact"" programs like setting up bank accounts, resiliency training, and other methods proven effective by extensive research. We are also developing gaming strategies that will continue to engage our constituents in ways that will increase their financial skills. We have already created successful programs with the Duke Federal Credit Union and Self-Help Credit Union that offer specialized savings accounts for our members. These include lower fees and minimum balances. Additionally, contributions to savings accounts through the Self-Help Credit Union go towards developing the local community. Finally, we already have signed up over 150 members to our group and are teaching a class to 12 Duke students about financial literacy. Because we are student run, we have low administrative overhead costs, which means your donations will go straight to the populations in greatest need through techniques that have proven effective over the years.
Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to support Duke/Durham Saves beyond financial contributions! If you know of any people or organizations that would be interested in either our services or partnering with us, please have them reach out to dukedurhamsaves@gmail.com so that we can continue to make a greater impact in the community. In addition, please sign up for our newsletter at www.dukedurhamsaves.org and send us any of your own savings tips in video or email format to dukedurhamsaves@gmail.com. Please help us spread the word about the importance of establishing early and worthwhile savings habits and share the campaign using social media and the Indiegogo share tools.

Thanks for all your support!

The kids build the boat...and the boat builds the kids

For the past decade Compass Project, a non-profit community-based program of Spurwink, has worked with hundreds of students throughout southern Maine to use boat building and rowing to provide positive direction to at-risk youth by encouraging the development of personal responsibility, community engagement, and environmental stewardship. Compass Project’s experiential learning programs integrate academic, job and life skills training with boat building and rowing to help youth stay in school, stay on track, and find new career directions.

Compass Project and Project Aspire and the Alternative Pathways Classroom at BiddefordHigh School are planning a two-semester collaborative boat building project to begin in the fall of 2013. This pilot program will benefit approximately 12-15 students who are eager for project-based learning opportunities that connect academic skills with real world applications.
column2: >For this program to be implemented, Compass Project and Biddeford High School must raise at least $5,000 by October 10th. After a successful pilot year, we expect the program cost to be incorporated into Biddeford’s budget for Special Education to continue a long-term collaboration into the future, and to partner with additional area schools to bring the program to even more area youth and their families.

column1: Denise Doherty, a teacher with Project Aspire, says:  “My goals are to open a new world to the students. Most of the students have very few skills in team work or applying academic skills to the real world or work. This collaboration could connect their knowledge beyond the classroom. They could improve math skills by relating it to boat building, and communication and team building skills by working with staff and students. Leaning how to use tools would greatly help my students gain hands-on skills that could benefit them in everyday life, such as repairs in their own homes, and increase their skills for employment.”
Why should you support this effort?

Biddeford has a rich boatbuilding history and a brightening future in the manufacturing and engineering industries. By engaging hard-to-reach students now in programs that will build their confidence, help them acquire and apply skills, and encourage the development of teamwork and communication skills, BiddefordHigh School and Compass Project will help these young people create a positive vision for their futures.
column2: >Your support of this program is an investment in tomorrow’s workforce – young men and women who have the potential to thrive in the workplace and the community, but need an innovative alternative to the traditional classroom.

column1: Please join in supporting this important effort today.

column2: >No gift is too small. And many gifts will add up quickly to help us reach the goal.

column1: Thank you!
